2. In property editor view, there is no corresponding property.

editor. Please refer to that.

Bug.Summery: [api] wst.wsdl APIs need javadoc

source_code.code: /** * Sets the value of the '{@link com.example.library.Book#getTitle Title}' attribute. * * * @param value the new value of the 'Title' attribute. * @see #getTitle() * @generated */

Bug.WithStack:
Refer to the javadoc coverage report for more info. Here's a recent report: http://download.eclipse.org/webtools/committers/drops/I-I200511162235- 200511162235/apiresults/api-javadoc-summary.html Or refer to the following document on how to generate the report locally: http://www.eclipse.org/webtools/development/apiscanner/apiscanner.html I find a small problem in adding Javadoc comments to these classes. It is because these classes are EMF-generated so next time when the classes are re-generated, chances are the Javadoc tags that are manually added would be gone. Let's take an example below. /** * Some documentation * * @model * @generated * @since 1.0 <-- add this manually */ public interface Binding extends ExtensibleElement, javax.wsdl.Binding { ... } The @since 1.0 tag would be gone next time Binding is re-generated. We may be able to modify @generated but then actual EMF model changes will not be reflected properly. Jeff, Ed, any thoughts/recommendations on this? Kihup, EMF generates a comment like this, with begin/end-user-doc, so that you can insert documentation with those brackets and not lose them. /** * Sets the value of the '{@link com.example.library.Book#getTitle Title}' attribute. * * * @param value the new value of the 'Title' attribute. * @see #getTitle() * @generated */ void setTitle(String value); During merging, the contents with the "brackets" are copied over. If you remove those brackets completel, the comment won't be replaced at all. After discussing with Ed, the following pattern should do the work. /** * * Some documentation * @since 1.0 * * @model * @generated */ public interface Binding extends ExtensibleElement, javax.wsdl.Binding { ... } Kihup, In the past I've seen problems with some Javadoc generators that don't treat *

* This will typically be a full URI representing the type of the annotation. *

* @see org.eclipse.emf.ecore.EModelElement#getEAnnotation(String) * @ignore * * @return the value of the 'Source' attribute. * @see #setSource(String) * @see org.eclipse.emf.ecore.EcorePackage#getEAnnotation_Source() * @model * @generated Created attachment 30623 apply to the plugin The patch includes API Javadoc comments and updated component.xml. Jeff, Please apply the patch before next API report generation. Kihup, the patch has been committed. Please resolve. Created attachment 30901 Apply to the class Keith, Please review and apply this patch to WSDLElement.java. Thanks, - Kihup Second patch applied. Thanks for the fix. Closing bug. Thanks for the fix. Closing bug.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Refer to the javadoc coverage report for more info. Here's a recent report: http://download.eclipse.org/webtools/committers/drops/I-I200511162235- 200511162235/apiresults/api-javadoc-summary.html Or refer to the following document on how to generate the report locally: http://www.eclipse.org/webtools/development/apiscanner/apiscanner.html I find a small problem in adding Javadoc comments to these classes. We may be able to modify @generated but then actual EMF model changes will not be reflected properly. Jeff, Ed, any thoughts/recommendations on this? Kihup, EMF generates a comment like this, with begin/end-user-doc, so that you can insert documentation with those brackets and not lose them. /** * Sets the value of the '{@link com.example.library.Book#getTitle Title}' attribute. * * * @param value the new value of the 'Title' attribute. * @see #getTitle() * @generated */ void setTitle(String value); During merging, the contents with the "brackets" are copied over. If you remove those brackets completel, the comment won't be replaced at all. After discussing with Ed, the following pattern should do the work. /** * * Some documentation * @since 1.0 * * @model * @generated */ public interface Binding extends ExtensibleElement, javax.wsdl.Binding { ... } Kihup, In the past I've seen problems with some Javadoc generators that don't treat *

Bug.Summery: [api] wst.sse APIs need more test coverage

Lines.Line: 1. I know we've set some bad examples, but we should simply throw all exceptions from JUnit tests (BadLocation in this case). This will cause the JUnit to fail visibly, if something Exceptional happens, instead of just printing stuff to log.

2. I provided a "fall through" failure in case the test paths (in the if/then claues) do not take the expected path. I think this is what caues failure in this my new version. I'm not sure exactly why it failes ... if timing? Or did I read it wrong? In either case ... I'll let you investigate.

Bug.WithStack:
Refer to the unit test coverage report for more info. Here's a recent report:
http://download.eclipse.org/webtools/committers/drops/I-I200511162235- 200511162235/apiresults/api-javadoc-summary.html I can take a look at this. okay, checked in the last of the unit tests needed into HEAD
plugin modified: org.eclipse.wst.sse.ui.tests
CC-ing David for approval. Thanks Amy, I "beefed up" this unit test in two ways, and will ask you to re-review ... since it now fails :)
1. I know we've set some bad examples, but we should simply throw all exceptions from JUnit tests (BadLocation in this case). This will cause the JUnit to fail visibly, if something Exceptional happens, instead of just printing stuff to log.
2. I provided a "fall through" failure in case the test paths (in the if/then claues) do not take the expected path. I think this is what caues failure in this my new version. I'm not sure exactly why it failes ... if timing? Or did I read it wrong? In either case ... I'll let you investigate.
Amy has pointed out my error (I forget to add a return, after adding the comment that "we must return at this point").
Thanks Amy, I have fixed and released.
Thanks for the fix. Closing bug.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Refer to the unit test coverage report for more info. Here's a recent report:
http://download.eclipse.org/webtools/committers/drops/I-I200511162235- 200511162235/apiresults/api-javadoc-summary.html I can take a look at this. okay, checked in the last of the unit tests needed into HEAD
plugin modified: org.eclipse.wst.sse.ui.tests
CC-ing David for approval. Thanks Amy, I "beefed up" this unit test in two ways, and will ask you to re-review ... since it now fails :)
1. I know we've set some bad examples, but we should simply throw all exceptions from JUnit tests (BadLocation in this case). This will cause the JUnit to fail visibly, if something Exceptional happens, instead of just printing stuff to log.
2. I provided a "fall through" failure in case the test paths (in the if/then claues) do not take the expected path. I think this is what caues failure in this my new version. I'm not sure exactly why it failes ... if timing? Or did I read it wrong? In either case ... I'll let you investigate.

Thanks Amy, I have fixed and released.
Thanks for the fix. Closing bug.

Bug.Summery: [package explorer] Show in package explorer multiple source path in one tree
Bug.WithStack: If you have multiple source pathes there should be the possibility to show all classes in one tree. Moving to JDT/UI No plans for this in the package explorer. But the browing perspective offers you that: if you select the project in the projects view, the packages and the types view then show the members of all source folders. I'd like to bump this bug if possible. With projects that have more than 20 or so source folders, it becomes quite cumbersome to use the package explorer. The Java browser is okay, but it is not something I would want to use for normal development. We have no plans or resources for this, sorry. Help is welcome! You could contribute this as a new view, or maybe hook in the common navigator framework to provide your view (project explorer).
Bug.WithOutStack: If you have multiple source pathes there should be the possibility to show all classes in one tree. Moving to JDT/UI No plans for this in the package explorer. But the browing perspective offers you that: if you select the project in the projects view, the packages and the types view then show the members of all source folders. I'd like to bump this bug if possible. With projects that have more than 20 or so source folders, it becomes quite cumbersome to use the package explorer. The Java browser is okay, but it is not something I would want to use for normal development. We have no plans or resources for this, sorry. Help is welcome! You could contribute this as a new view, or maybe hook in the common navigator framework to provide your view (project explorer).

Bug.Summery: Run subreport1.xml to generate pdf file but get Outofmemory error and pdf file cannot be open.
Bug.WithStack:
Description: Run subreport1.xml to generate pdf file but get Outofmemory error and pdf file cannot be open.
Steps to reproduce: 1. run attached design file to generate pdf file
Expected result: pdf file can be previewed.
Actual result: When open the pdf file, I got below message: could not open 'subReport1.pdf' because it is either not a supported file type or because the file has been corrupted.
Please found attached old generated fo file Created attachment 30121 design file It's not a regression bug. memeory limitation exists in FOP 0.20.5. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Description: Run subreport1.xml to generate pdf file but get Outofmemory error and pdf file cannot be open.
Steps to reproduce: 1. run attached design file to generate pdf file
Expected result: pdf file can be previewed.
Actual result: When open the pdf file, I got below message: could not open 'subReport1.pdf' because it is either not a supported file type or because the file has been corrupted.
Please found attached old generated fo file Created attachment 30121 design file It's not a regression bug. memeory limitation exists in FOP 0.20.5. Verified.

Bug.Summery: Label height doesn't change with label font modification.

Lines.Line: 1. Add a label and edit its font size as "18 points".
2. Label height is not changed right after setting in UI.
3. Change label content, its height can be justified with the font size.
*** Bug 112909 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
This caused by eclipse changes of Figure:setFont() method. Under 3.0, this feature is ok. But under 3.1, it's not working. Call InvalidateTree to force refresh of children.

Bug.WithStack:
Description: Label font size doesn't change right away it is modified.
Steps to reproduce: 1. Add a label and edit its font size as "18 points". 2. Label height is not changed right after setting in UI. 3. Change label content, its height can be justified with the font size. *** Bug 112909 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This caused by eclipse changes of Figure:setFont() method. Under 3.0, this feature is ok. But under 3.1, it's not working. Call InvalidateTree to force refresh of children.
Verified in build 20051206.

Bug.Summery: Changes to New Server wizard to help users manage runtimes.

Lines.Line: 1. Actually the wizard lets user choose a runtime instance, if more than one
instance of the server type is configured. Maybe we can make this selection a
permanent one and call the runtime wizard if user chooses <new Runtime>. Tim
(DeBoer) what do you think about this?
2. I can make this change for the generic server framework, I assume that the
drop down will include the runtimes compatible with the chosen server type. Is
that correct?
Just to reiterate, the confusion we're seeing is that our customers don't see
the distinction between creating a runtime and creating a server when the
current behavior is to create a runtime almost as a byproduct of creating the
first server of that type. Subsequently, when the delete a server, they are
mostly unaware that there is a runtime still lurking in their preferences. I
believe we need to make them more aware of the fact that runtimes are registered
in preferences.
1. If there are no Runtimes created yet. (that is runtime and server
is created together) The combo is empty so I do not show the Runtime
combo.
2. If there is more than one runtimes, the Runtime selection combo in
generic server wizard is trivial since same combo is present in the
Runtime type selection.
1) Create a workspace that has one runtime registered (for example by creating a server)
2) Run the New Server wizard, and choose the server type that corresponds to the registered runtime type
3) Click on the Server Runtime Preferences and in the preferences, delete the runtime (you can create a new one if you like).
4) Upon returning to the New Server wizard the Next button proceeds directly to the Generic server properties page - it skips the Generic server runtime properties fragment.

5) After completing the wizard, the server created is tied to a runtime that no longer exists. Worse, there is no visual indicator to the user that something has gone wrong - they might attempt to start the server and not know they made a mistake when creating it.
- the wizard should always show a page allowing the user to choose a runtime
instance that matches the chosen server type
- the runtime wizard page should contain a drop down list of existing server
runtimes and a hyperlink to the server runtime preferences, in exactly the same
way that the server runtime page currently prompts the user to choose a JRE.
(i.e. "You can use_ Installed Server Runtimes_ to create a new Server, followed
by a Server Runtimes: drop down.
[From Gorkem Ecran]
This is very valuable feedback because the UI part of generic servers was quite
different before WTP. I would like to have those changes but I should also warn
that we are very close to M9 and the end game so we may not be able to get to
many changes/features in for 1.0.
For the changes I have a few comments. The confusion about runtimes and
servers is not an issue related to generic servers only any server adapter that
allows 1-N relation between runtime and server will suffer from the same. So
some of the changes may need to be worked on up in the server framework level.
1. Actually the wizard lets user choose a runtime instance, if more than one
instance of the server type is configured. Maybe we can make this selection a
permanent one and call the runtime wizard if user chooses <new Runtime>. Tim
(DeBoer) what do you think about this?
2. I can make this change for the generic server framework, I assume that the
drop down will include the runtimes compatible with the chosen server type. Is
that correct?
Just to reiterate, the confusion we're seeing is that our customers don't see
the distinction between creating a runtime and creating a server when the
current behavior is to create a runtime almost as a byproduct of creating the
first server of that type. Subsequently, when the delete a server, they are
mostly unaware that there is a runtime still lurking in their preferences. I
believe we need to make them more aware of the fact that runtimes are registered
in preferences.
- if the user has no runtimes then it will be empty (and the Next/Finish buttons
disabled). They will be forced to use the hyperlink.
- if the user has one or more runtimes then the first can be selected by defult.
The can change to any entry. If they choose to add a new runtime then can use
the hyperlink to do so and when they return select the new entry from the dropdown.

Bug.WithStack:
We're finding our beta customers are still struggling with how the generic server instances tie in with runtimes - basically they don't usually realise that the runtimes still exist in their preferences and therefore complain when the new server wizard doesn't allow them to specify the runtime properties (install location etc) on the second and subsequent runs for a particular (generic) server type. Typically these customers have more than one installation of a particular server runtime that they want to use from the same workbench.
The feedback we are getting is leading us towards suggesting changing the New Server generic wizard pages as follows: - the wizard should always show a page allowing the user to choose a runtime instance that matches the chosen server type - the runtime wizard page should contain a drop down list of existing server runtimes and a hyperlink to the server runtime preferences, in exactly the same way that the server runtime page currently prompts the user to choose a JRE. (i.e. "You can use_ Installed Server Runtimes_ to create a new Server, followed by a Server Runtimes: drop down. [From Gorkem Ecran] This is very valuable feedback because the UI part of generic servers was quite different before WTP. I would like to have those changes but I should also warn that we are very close to M9 and the end game so we may not be able to get to many changes/features in for 1.0. For the changes I have a few comments. The confusion about runtimes and servers is not an issue related to generic servers only any server adapter that allows 1-N relation between runtime and server will suffer from the same. So some of the changes may need to be worked on up in the server framework level. 1. Actually the wizard lets user choose a runtime instance, if more than one instance of the server type is configured. Maybe we can make this selection a permanent one and call the runtime wizard if user chooses <new Runtime>. Tim (DeBoer) what do you think about this? 2. I can make this change for the generic server framework, I assume that the drop down will include the runtimes compatible with the chosen server type. Is that correct? Just to reiterate, the confusion we're seeing is that our customers don't see the distinction between creating a runtime and creating a server when the current behavior is to create a runtime almost as a byproduct of creating the first server of that type. Subsequently, when the delete a server, they are mostly unaware that there is a runtime still lurking in their preferences. I believe we need to make them more aware of the fact that runtimes are registered in preferences.
This is why I was suggesting separating the two tasks, so that the user is clearly lead to the preferences panel in order to create/edit/delete runtimes. The New Server wizard is then used by users creating new servers only (they can jump out to the "installed runtimes" preferences panel via the hyperlink in order to manipulate the list of runtimes they can choose from). The addition of a "New Runtime" wizard would be a "nice to have" only.
I'm not quite sure why we need different behavior in the 'choose runtime 'wizard page depending on whether the workspace has zero, one or more than one matching runtime. I was thinking that the the runtime combo should be presented using whatever information is registered in the preferences - if the user has no runtimes then it will be empty (and the Next/Finish buttons disabled). They will be forced to use the hyperlink. - if the user has one or more runtimes then the first can be selected by defult. The can change to any entry. If they choose to add a new runtime then can use the hyperlink to do so and when they return select the new entry from the dropdown.
Perhaps we are both describing the same thing? [From Gorkem Ecran]
I have an initial implementation ready for generic servers I think I can release this for tonight' s I-build. But after using the real implementation I must say this new feature is useful if there is exacty one runtime created beforehand. 1. If there are no Runtimes created yet. (that is runtime and server is created together) The combo is empty so I do not show the Runtime combo. 2. If there is more than one runtimes, the Runtime selection combo in generic server wizard is trivial since same combo is present in the Runtime type selection.
I think a better usage would be to change the runtime selection page so that the Runtime combo is displayed when there is one or more runtimes of selected type. We may also add a link to the Installed Runtimes preference page. I can help with a patch for this. Tim, what do you think?
Gorkem. I agree that we need to emphasize runtimes and servers are different but right now we are at a point that we will not be able to make dramatic changes to our UI. My current changes are only related to generic server wizard pages, but the runtimes combo is displayed in the first page of the server wizard (if there is more than one runtime of the selected runtime type). As a result my changes in some situations puts a second combo in the second page of the wizard and I am not very comfortable with this.
So I think a better solution would be to change the behavior of the original combo and add the hyper link to preferences, but since this is in the wst.ui, it is better if Tim comments on this. [From Tim Deboer]
I agree that runtime selection/creation should be accessible directly from the New Server wizard. We need to keep the UI minimal and simple (we don't want to complicate things for users who don't know/care about what runtimes are), but it's currently too simple and doesn't include function that should be there. Personally, I would like to keep the embedded runtime creation available (e.g. via a 'create a new runtime' option in the combo), but I like the other suggestions and I'll try to see what works.
Created attachment 30404 new server wizard patch
A patch to the new server wizard that adds a link to new Runtime preferences. (In reply to comment #6) > Created an attachment (id=30404) [edit] > new server wizard patch > > A patch to the new server wizard that adds a link to new Runtime preferences. >
Gorkem, Looks good, it is definately an improvement. I'm not sure what scope is left for further UI changes to New Server Instance wizard but I believe that the "Select the server type" control on the first page of the New Server Instance wizard does not belong there - this control is related to server runtime creation, not part of the server instance creation (and in fact it is reused in the New Server Runtime wizard (when started via preferences->servers->installed runtimes->new) Si I would propose as a further improvement that the New Server Instance wizard first page should only have a Server Runtime dropdown (and this new link to the Runtime preferences). This is the exact same convention used in the New Server Runtime Wizard - it has a drop down of JRE's and a link to the JRE preferences and this works nicely. I agree that this turns creating a logical server into a two stage process but I think this is unavoidable - given how the rest of the framework behaves, the user needs to know that a logical server is acutually made up of associated two components (runtime and instance). The current New Server Instance wizard implementation does not make this clear in the trivial case where the user is creating their first server runtime and first server instance, and in other cases the user has to re-specify a server type when all they really should be doing is picking from a list of existing runtimes (or going off into prefs to create a new runtime)
Sachin's changes checked into HEAD and will be tagged for next build shortly. I made a minor change to switch the link to a button (thought this was more consistent with the JDT), but we can evaluate further once this is in a build.
I would like to see other changes but at the current point I don't think we can take the most recently suggestions given that it wouldn't match the model (it allows servers that don't have runtimes) and we're looking at a fairly small number of servers, most of which don't take advantage of server level settings (e.g. Tomcat wizard allows you to change the runtime settings, but doesn't allow you to configure the Tomcat config options, etc). I plan to close this bug with the current changes and we can always discuss other changes via a new bug. Tim by Sachin' s changes do you mean my patch :) Fix released. (In reply to comment #8) > I would like to see other changes but at the current point I don't think we can > take the most recently suggestions given that it wouldn't match the model (it > allows servers that don't have runtimes) and we're looking at a fairly small > number of servers, most of which don't take advantage of server level settings > (e.g. Tomcat wizard allows you to change the runtime settings, but doesn't > allow you to configure the Tomcat config options, etc).
Just a quick note on your comment - you mention that my suggestion would break the model because "it allows servers that don't have runtimes". That certainly isn't the intention - all servers definatly need a runtime, even with the suggested change. Perhaps I didn't explain correctly - the suggestion is when the New Server Instance wizard is run, that the very first page displayed only contains a dropdown list of existing registered runtimes, and a link (or button) to the Installed Runtimes preferences page. The user should not be able to get past that page until they either pick or create a runtime...
Also note that our servers (based on generic server f/work) do have a number of server properties (as well as runtime properties) that we require the user to specify as our publisher needs a few of them in order to connect to the server (it publishes via SOAP)
I plan to close this > bug with the current changes and we can always discuss other changes via a new > bug. >
I'll open a new bug so.
BTW, we actually do support 'servers without runtime instances'. If a server has no files on disk or doesn't need a classpath, etc., then you can actually provide support for creating server instances without creating a runtime instance. An example might be a remote HTTP server. I agree it's an edge case, just FYI. Um, yeah, I did mean Gorkem's patch in comment 8. Sorry, I worked with a guy named Sachin for a while, must have been emailing him at the same time and typed the name in the wrong window. :) I'm afraid I've come across a use case where that the patch fails to account for:
1) Create a workspace that has one runtime registered (for example by creating a server) 2) Run the New Server wizard, and choose the server type that corresponds to the registered runtime type 3) Click on the Server Runtime Preferences and in the preferences, delete the runtime (you can create a new one if you like). 4) Upon returning to the New Server wizard the Next button proceeds directly to the Generic server properties page - it skips the Generic server runtime properties fragment. 5) After completing the wizard, the server created is tied to a runtime that no longer exists. Worse, there is no visual indicator to the user that something has gone wrong - they might attempt to start the server and not know they made a mistake when creating it.
The workaround for this is for the user to Edit the existing runtime, not delete it (and/or create a new one)
The reason this is happening is that the NewManualServerComposite is holding a cache of ServerWorkingCopy objects. Each server working copy contains a reference to either a Runtime or RuntimeWorkingCopy - it depends on whether a runtime existed in the workspace when the server working copy was added to the cache.
The problem is deleting the runtime via the preferences after the cache is populated means the ServerWorkingCopy has a reference to a runtime that should no longer exist. Subsequently, the wizard framework thinks there is no need to show the runtime wizard fragment and skips straight on to the server wizard fragment. Unfortunately, that leaves the server in an unrunnable state (presuming the old runtime is really gone, that is).
I guess the fix is to either rebuild the cache after every time the user comes back from the server runtime preferences as they may have deleted runtimes associated with any number of server types...
Any comment on the status of this one? I'm reviewing our open issues with the hope of getting them all resolved for 1.0.1 as some were deferred from the 1.0 release.
Thanks,
John. A couple fixes to invalidate the wizard's cache and runtime reference went into 1.5 and I missed updating this bug. I've tested again, and I cannot reproduce this problem - when you return from deleting the runtime in preferences, the wizard correctly refreshes and you get the next page that allows you to configure the runtime. The server is created successfully along with a new runtime.
Since this appears to be fixed I am resolving the bug. Thanks Tim, looks good now. This is part of a "mass update" where bugs showing "fixed" between 7/1/2006 and 9/27/2006 are assumed fixed in WTP 1.5.1. feel free to change the target milestone if you know a more accurate setting.

I think a better usage would be to change the runtime selection page so that the Runtime combo is displayed when there is one or more runtimes of selected type. We may also add a link to the Installed Runtimes preference page. I can help with a patch for this. Tim, what do you think?
Gorkem. I agree that we need to emphasize runtimes and servers are different but right now we are at a point that we will not be able to make dramatic changes to our UI. My current changes are only related to generic server wizard pages, but the runtimes combo is displayed in the first page of the server wizard (if there is more than one runtime of the selected runtime type). As a result my changes in some situations puts a second combo in the second page of the wizard and I am not very comfortable with this.
So I think a better solution would be to change the behavior of the original combo and add the hyper link to preferences, but since this is in the wst.ui, it is better if Tim comments on this. [From Tim Deboer]
I agree that runtime selection/creation should be accessible directly from the New Server wizard. We need to keep the UI minimal and simple (we don't want to complicate things for users who don't know/care about what runtimes are), but it's currently too simple and doesn't include function that should be there. Personally, I would like to keep the embedded runtime creation available (e.g. via a 'create a new runtime' option in the combo), but I like the other suggestions and I'll try to see what works.
Created attachment 30404 new server wizard patch
A patch to the new server wizard that adds a link to new Runtime preferences. (In reply to comment #6) > Created an attachment (id=30404) [edit] > new server wizard patch > > A patch to the new server wizard that adds a link to new Runtime preferences. >
Gorkem, Looks good, it is definately an improvement. I'm not sure what scope is left for further UI changes to New Server Instance wizard but I believe that the "Select the server type" control on the first page of the New Server Instance wizard does not belong there - this control is related to server runtime creation, not part of the server instance creation (and in fact it is reused in the New Server Runtime wizard (when started via preferences->servers->installed runtimes->new) Si I would propose as a further improvement that the New Server Instance wizard first page should only have a Server Runtime dropdown (and this new link to the Runtime preferences). This is the exact same convention used in the New Server Runtime Wizard - it has a drop down of JRE's and a link to the JRE preferences and this works nicely. I agree that this turns creating a logical server into a two stage process but I think this is unavoidable - given how the rest of the framework behaves, the user needs to know that a logical server is acutually made up of associated two components (runtime and instance). The current New Server Instance wizard implementation does not make this clear in the trivial case where the user is creating their first server runtime and first server instance, and in other cases the user has to re-specify a server type when all they really should be doing is picking from a list of existing runtimes (or going off into prefs to create a new runtime)
Sachin's changes checked into HEAD and will be tagged for next build shortly. I made a minor change to switch the link to a button (thought this was more consistent with the JDT), but we can evaluate further once this is in a build.
I would like to see other changes but at the current point I don't think we can take the most recently suggestions given that it wouldn't match the model (it allows servers that don't have runtimes) and we're looking at a fairly small number of servers, most of which don't take advantage of server level settings (e.g. Tomcat wizard allows you to change the runtime settings, but doesn't allow you to configure the Tomcat config options, etc). I plan to close this bug with the current changes and we can always discuss other changes via a new bug. Tim by Sachin' s changes do you mean my patch :) Fix released. (In reply to comment #8) > I would like to see other changes but at the current point I don't think we can > take the most recently suggestions given that it wouldn't match the model (it > allows servers that don't have runtimes) and we're looking at a fairly small > number of servers, most of which don't take advantage of server level settings > (e.g. Tomcat wizard allows you to change the runtime settings, but doesn't > allow you to configure the Tomcat config options, etc).
Just a quick note on your comment - you mention that my suggestion would break the model because "it allows servers that don't have runtimes". That certainly isn't the intention - all servers definatly need a runtime, even with the suggested change. Perhaps I didn't explain correctly - the suggestion is when the New Server Instance wizard is run, that the very first page displayed only contains a dropdown list of existing registered runtimes, and a link (or button) to the Installed Runtimes preferences page. The user should not be able to get past that page until they either pick or create a runtime...
Also note that our servers (based on generic server f/work) do have a number of server properties (as well as runtime properties) that we require the user to specify as our publisher needs a few of them in order to connect to the server (it publishes via SOAP)
I plan to close this > bug with the current changes and we can always discuss other changes via a new > bug. >
I'll open a new bug so.
BTW, we actually do support 'servers without runtime instances'. If a server has no files on disk or doesn't need a classpath, etc., then you can actually provide support for creating server instances without creating a runtime instance. An example might be a remote HTTP server. I agree it's an edge case, just FYI. Um, yeah, I did mean Gorkem's patch in comment 8. Sorry, I worked with a guy named Sachin for a while, must have been emailing him at the same time and typed the name in the wrong window. :) I'm afraid I've come across a use case where that the patch fails to account for:
1) Create a workspace that has one runtime registered (for example by creating a server) 2) Run the New Server wizard, and choose the server type that corresponds to the registered runtime type 3) Click on the Server Runtime Preferences and in the preferences, delete the runtime (you can create a new one if you like). 4) Upon returning to the New Server wizard the Next button proceeds directly to the Generic server properties page - it skips the Generic server runtime properties fragment. 5) After completing the wizard, the server created is tied to a runtime that no longer exists. Worse, there is no visual indicator to the user that something has gone wrong - they might attempt to start the server and not know they made a mistake when creating it.
The workaround for this is for the user to Edit the existing runtime, not delete it (and/or create a new one)
The reason this is happening is that the NewManualServerComposite is holding a cache of ServerWorkingCopy objects. Each server working copy contains a reference to either a Runtime or RuntimeWorkingCopy - it depends on whether a runtime existed in the workspace when the server working copy was added to the cache.
The problem is deleting the runtime via the preferences after the cache is populated means the ServerWorkingCopy has a reference to a runtime that should no longer exist. Subsequently, the wizard framework thinks there is no need to show the runtime wizard fragment and skips straight on to the server wizard fragment. Unfortunately, that leaves the server in an unrunnable state (presuming the old runtime is really gone, that is).
I guess the fix is to either rebuild the cache after every time the user comes back from the server runtime preferences as they may have deleted runtimes associated with any number of server types...
Any comment on the status of this one? I'm reviewing our open issues with the hope of getting them all resolved for 1.0.1 as some were deferred from the 1.0 release.
Thanks,
John. A couple fixes to invalidate the wizard's cache and runtime reference went into 1.5 and I missed updating this bug. I've tested again, and I cannot reproduce this problem - when you return from deleting the runtime in preferences, the wizard correctly refreshes and you get the next page that allows you to configure the runtime. The server is created successfully along with a new runtime.
Since this appears to be fixed I am resolving the bug. Thanks Tim, looks good now. This is part of a "mass update" where bugs showing "fixed" between 7/1/2006 and 9/27/2006 are assumed fixed in WTP 1.5.1. feel free to change the target milestone if you know a more accurate setting.

Bug.Summery: Dynamic html ouput in PDF
Bug.WithStack:
Hello,
we stored product catalog descriptions (text with html format information) in a database field and created a report with a text field of type html/dynamic: <VALUE-OF format=html>row["Infotext"]</VALUE-OF>.
The report consists of two columns, a part no and the above descriped text field.
The html format information would be correctly interpreted for the html output preview of the report.
In the pdf-output preview the tags would be removed and only the pure text information has been shown (with a page break before the html tag).
We used Birt Version 2.0, Build M2, Eclipse 3.1, Jdk 1.4.2_4, for Adobe - Version 6.0.0. Fixed in BIRT PDF emitter Verified in build 20051219

Bug.Summery: [typing] Need much smart encoding error detection for text save

source_code.code: /** * Returns the plug-in-specific status code describing the outcome. * * @return plug-in-specific status code */

Lines.Line: - throws an exception upon creation if the encoding itself is not supported
- IOException if the writing fails
Can you point me to the method (and spec) that says the writer is checking
whether a character is legal in the specified encoding.
- Notepad warns this mis-match encoding and suggests us to use the
unicode. Also other commercial editors check this encoding error.
- OutputStream<init>(OutputStream out, CharsetEncoder enc) accepts
CharsetEncoder. According to CharsetEncoder, its doc says :
How an encoding error is handled depends upon the action requested
for that type of error, which is described by an instance of the
CodingErrorAction class
And CodingErrorAction#REPORT doc says :
Action indicating that a coding error is to be reported, either
by returning a CoderResult object or by throwing a
CharacterCodingException, whichever is appropriate for the method
implementing the coding process.
- for the file buffers: IFileBufferStatusCodes.CHARSET_MAPPING_FAILED
- for document providers: EditorsUI.CHARSET_MAPPING_FAILED

Bug.WithStack:
When the document has the characters which can't be converted to the specified encoding and it is saved, no error is reported so that it gives the users that the save is ok. However, when the editor is closed and the same document is opened again, such characters are all changed to '?'. ( This is because java converter changes all such characters to '?' ). For example, if Window > Preferences > Workbench > Editors > Text file encoding is set to US-ASCII, and the text file is opened by TextEditor and the non US-ASCII characters are entered ( all they are doable now ), and finally that file is saved, no error is reported. However, after that document is closed and is opened again, there are '?' characters. This is a surpirse for the users so that it would be best if the save detected this kind of invalid character errors and reported this to the users. For example, OutputStreamWriter#write throws UnmappableCharacterException, so we can detect this kind of encoding errors. >the non US-ASCII characters >are entered ( all they are doable now ) How do you do it? Copy/Paste? The only way to detect this is to re-read the saved file and then compare it to the editor content. This significantly slows down save performance. > How do you do it? Copy/Paste? If you are using non US locale OS, you can do it. In my environment, I'm always using Japanese Win OS locale and I can set up US-ASCII to the preference though TextEditor can accept Japanese characters from IM. > The only way to detect this is to re-read the saved file OutputStreamWriter can throw the exception. There is no need to re-read the file. What do other editors do in that situation (e.g. Notepad)? >OutputStreamWriter can throw the exception. There is no need >to re-read the file. AFAIK it - throws an exception upon creation if the encoding itself is not supported - IOException if the writing fails Can you point me to the method (and spec) that says the writer is checking whether a character is legal in the specified encoding. - Notepad warns this mis-match encoding and suggests us to use the unicode. Also other commercial editors check this encoding error. - OutputStream(OutputStream out, CharsetEncoder enc) accepts CharsetEncoder. According to CharsetEncoder, its doc says : How an encoding error is handled depends upon the action requested for that type of error, which is described by an instance of the CodingErrorAction class And CodingErrorAction#REPORT doc says : Action indicating that a coding error is to be reported, either by returning a CoderResult object or by throwing a CharacterCodingException, whichever is appropriate for the method implementing the coding process. I think they are good starting point for you to investigate this problem. . Just FYI, I agree that saving text, and "losing data" due to charset mismatch, without warning user really is "losing data". We used to handle/gaurd against this in SSE layer ... but, since "the platform" now handles encoding/charset "the platform" is the right place to handle this. I'd suggest a user choice "cancel save" or "save anyway" sort of choice. (And, of course, its really that "model layer" that needs to throw an exception, and let the UI layer decide how to handle it). (In reply to comment #5) > I'd suggest a user choice > "cancel save" or "save anyway" sort of choice. I think this choice is enough for users to see there are some encoding error so that this 'save' may cause some data-loss error. . *** Bug 128026 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This is now correctly handled by file buffers and document providers: they throw a CoreException with a custom status code if the mapping fails. - for the file buffers: IFileBufferStatusCodes.CHARSET_MAPPING_FAILED - for document providers: EditorsUI.CHARSET_MAPPING_FAILED The editor reports this to the user and suggests to either change the encoding or the offending characters. Fixed in HEAD. Available in builds > N20060224-0010. Out of curiosity, do you need to define the status constant as API in two places? Presumably any client of EditorsUI will also have the filebuffers plugin available? John, as you can see from IStatus.getCode(): /** * Returns the plug-in-specific status code describing the outcome. * * @return plug-in-specific status code */ public int getCode(); the value space for the code is per plug-in. If we used the same value in file buffers and Editors UI we'd have to make sure the codes don't overlap and that's a burden we don't want to take. Ok, makes sense. CCing Mcq for PMC approval of this new API. The new API is two status code constants (ints). The constants allow a client to distinguish a generic failure from failure to save due to presence of characters that can not be saved in the chosen encoding. >Ok, makes sense. CCing Mcq for PMC approval of this new API. Note that one constant is added to a final class and the other constant is added to a constant interface which is marked as: *

* Clients are not supposed to implement that interface. *

and also correctly listed in the component.xml. That's why I did not raise this as being an API change. Makes sense to me. Verified using I20060328-0010
Bug.WithOutStack:
When the document has the characters which can't be converted to the specified encoding and it is saved, no error is reported so that it gives the users that the save is ok. However, when the editor is closed and the same document is opened again, such characters are all changed to '?'. ( This is because java converter changes all such characters to '?' ). For example, if Window > Preferences > Workbench > Editors > Text file encoding is set to US-ASCII, and the text file is opened by TextEditor and the non US-ASCII characters are entered ( all they are doable now ), and finally that file is saved, no error is reported. Bug.Summery: new feature installer should warn user when Execution Environment is not enough to run
Bug.WithStack:
I20051116-1332
See bug 98798. If a plug-in specifies Bundle-RequiredExecutionEnvironment: J2SE-1.5 , but the running eclipse instance uses a 1.4 JRE, then the plug-in will not be able to run.
Currently, the install is silently accepted, and even during the restart of the workbench, there's no message in the log and the bundle is not activated. The install wizard should let users know at the earliest possibility that the plug-in will not work unless the execution environment is changed.
When e.g. installing the java-element-view-1.0.0 from http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/jdt-ui-home/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.astview/AST-View-Site , the user has no clue why it doesn't work, unless she started eclipse with the -dev option (which writes a developer-oriented message to the log).
Maybe, there should even be an option in the feature or the site.xml that shows/checks the minimal EE requirements.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 113956 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
I20051116-1332

Bug.Summery: Errors when building ant projects

Lines.Line: 1. bring source of problematic projects into your workspace. Currently ant.core
will build properly if you have core.runtime in your workspace. ant.ui could be
uglier.
2. right-click each plugin's plugin.xml and use "PDE Tools/Create Ant Build
File" to generate a build.xml. Run that build file to generate the missing jars.
(PDE handles the new version numbers correctly).

Bug.WithStack:
org.eclipse.ant.ui and org.eclipse.ant.core from HEAD as of now.

properties:

Maybe it's a user error but I didn't change anything in my workspace and this used to work.
Build id: I20051116-1332. This is caused by the recent changes to jar file names. We expect a jar called org.eclipse.core.runtime_3.1.0, but the file name is now something like org.eclipse.core.runtime_3.1.100.v20051114.jar. Investigating a fix. work-arounds: 1. bring source of problematic projects into your workspace. Currently ant.core will build properly if you have core.runtime in your workspace. ant.ui could be uglier.
2. right-click each plugin's plugin.xml and use "PDE Tools/Create Ant Build File" to generate a build.xml. Run that build file to generate the missing jars. (PDE handles the new version numbers correctly).
Created attachment 30170 patch for ant.core Created attachment 30172 patch for ant.ui attached patch 30170 and patch 30172 convert the build file to use a <dirset> and <fileset> when defining the classpath. This allows us to use the * wildcard instead of a ${version_suffix} property. The old approach is not going to work anymore as every plugin could have a different version for every build. Created attachment 30184 better patch for ant.ui
fixes remote jar also. fixed in HEAD DarinS, please verify. Verified.

org.eclipse.ant.ui and org.eclipse.ant.core from HEAD as of now.

Maybe it's a user error but I didn't change anything in my workspace and this used to work.
Build id: I20051116-1332. This is caused by the recent changes to jar file names. We expect a jar called org.eclipse.core.runtime_3.1.0, but the file name is now something like org.eclipse.core.runtime_3.1.100.v20051114.jar. Investigating a fix. work-arounds: 1. bring source of problematic projects into your workspace. Currently ant.core will build properly if you have core.runtime in your workspace. ant.ui could be uglier.
2. right-click each plugin's plugin.xml and use "PDE Tools/Create Ant Build File" to generate a build.xml. Run that build file to generate the missing jars. (PDE handles the new version numbers correctly).
Created attachment 30170 patch for ant.core Created attachment 30172 patch for ant.ui attached patch 30170 and patch 30172 convert the build file to use a <dirset> and <fileset> when defining the classpath. This allows us to use the * wildcard instead of a ${version_suffix} property. The old approach is not going to work anymore as every plugin could have a different version for every build. Created attachment 30184 better patch for ant.ui
fixes remote jar also. fixed in HEAD DarinS, please verify. Verified.

Bug.Summery: All ITDs appear as public and static in the outline and other views
Bug.WithStack:
If you install the Bean Example project and open BoundPoint.aj you will notice that all the ITDs appear a public (green circles) and static (red 'S' decoration), despite the fact that none of them are static and one of them is private. This bug was caused because the parser produces two modifiers for itds - the modifiers for the itd, which are public and static, and the declared modifiers, which are the modifiers for the declared fiels, method or constructor. I switched to using the declared modifiers. Fixed in the following builds:
AJDT 1.2.1 for Eclipse 3.0: BUILD COMPLETE - build.583 Date of build: 11/24/2005 11:57:19 Time to build: 35 minutes 35 seconds
AJDT 1.3 for Eclipse 3.1: BUILD COMPLETE - build.23 Date of build: 11/24/2005 06:28:27 Time to build: 15 minutes 35 seconds
Bug.WithOutStack:
If you install the Bean Example project and open BoundPoint.aj you will notice that all the ITDs appear a public (green circles) and static (red 'S' decoration), despite the fact that none of them are static and one of them is private. This bug was caused because the parser produces two modifiers for itds - the modifiers for the itd, which are public and static, and the declared modifiers, which are the modifiers for the declared fiels, method or constructor. I switched to using the declared modifiers. Fixed in the following builds:
AJDT 1.2.1 for Eclipse 3.0: BUILD COMPLETE - build.583 Date of build: 11/24/2005 11:57:19 Time to build: 35 minutes 35 seconds
AJDT 1.3 for Eclipse 3.1: BUILD COMPLETE - build.23 Date of build: 11/24/2005 06:28:27 Time to build: 15 minutes 35 seconds

Bug.Summery: Clean: More information for the user
Bug.WithStack:
20051117
The worst thing an IDE can do is deleting files it shouldn't and destroy some work. One place where deleting happes is in the 'clean' of builders. We do the best to warn when configuring a builder (e.g. in the Java case when setting the classpath), but some scenarios are only detected when actially doing the clean.
Problem is, the builder has no possibilty to communicate through UI.
One idea is that builders could offer a list of folders that they will delete. E.g. This information could be used in the clean dialog, we could not only show the projects being cleaned, but give a list of files that are cleaned and show them to the user.
-> IncrementalProjectBuilder.getResourcesToBeCleaned Something along the line of offering 'details' pane in clean dialog. Builder issue.
Bug.WithOutStack:
20051117
The worst thing an IDE can do is deleting files it shouldn't and destroy some work. One place where deleting happes is in the 'clean' of builders. We do the best to warn when configuring a builder (e.g. in the Java case when setting the classpath), but some scenarios are only detected when actially doing the clean.
Problem is, the builder has no possibilty to communicate through UI.
One idea is that builders could offer a list of folders that they will delete. E.g. This information could be used in the clean dialog, we could not only show the projects being cleaned, but give a list of files that are cleaned and show them to the user.
-> IncrementalProjectBuilder.getResourcesToBeCleaned Something along the line of offering 'details' pane in clean dialog. Builder issue.

Bug.Summery: Code is not synchronized properly with server
Bug.WithStack:
In general, when I make alterations to a JSP page the changes are not deployed to the server when doing a "run on server"/"debug on server".
This also goes for Java code although it is only sometimes that the code running on the server is not updated.
Usually it can be fixed by doing a project-clean. Cleaning both the dynamic web project and the enclosing ear project. This is not that great a work around though since on a large project this is very time consuming.
I use OC4J as application server using the generic server definitions. I have made my own definitions for OC4J. I do not think that this is what causing the problems though.
Kind regards Anders Svendsen I believe this is due to builder that updates .deployables. This builder and .deployables is removed for 1.0
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 97756 *** This bug was moved to 'closed' state, since it is so old is is assumed its dup, invalid, or worksforme resolution is no longer in qustion and the bugzilla needs no further attention. Feel free to re-open, or open a new bug, if this semi-automatic processing was done in error in this case.
Bug.WithOutStack:
In general, when I make alterations to a JSP page the changes are not deployed to the server when doing a "run on server"/"debug on server".
This also goes for Java code although it is only sometimes that the code running on the server is not updated.
Usually it can be fixed by doing a project-clean. Cleaning both the dynamic web project and the enclosing ear project. This is not that great a work around though since on a large project this is very time consuming.
I use OC4J as application server using the generic server definitions. I have made my own definitions for OC4J. I do not think that this is what causing the problems though.
Kind regards Anders Svendsen I believe this is due to builder that updates .deployables. This builder and .deployables is removed for 1.0

I moved back to last weeks I-Build and the workspace came back. But now I moved back up to I20051116-1332 and I cannot seem to reproduce. I think this is core.resources problem. I also moved back to last week I-Build and my workspace came back. However, I still get these exceptions when I tried again to switch on I20051116-1332 after... Note that I can open a brand new workspace or a real simple old one (just one project Test in it with one class Test...). But I get these exceptions with all my other workspaces (at least all o.e.jdt.core* projects loaded in it).
I think you will get the failure when a workspace contains a project that is outside the default location... I will work on a fix/patch. Is there any possible workaround waiting for this patch (except than remove external project of course...)?
I suggest staying on the previous integration build until I have a patch. *** Bug 116874 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I have released the fix to HEAD. A patch that works on any I-build from this week is available here:
http://eclipse.org/eclipse/platform-core/downloads.html#patches
Don't forget to restart with -clean after dropping the patch in your plugins directory. Thanks to our new qualified version numbers it is not necessary to delete the old jar first. I will also send a note to platform-releng-dev. Marking fixed. And, sorry for the headaches this probably caused. I renamed the "Assert" class in core.resources to prevent a collision with the new Assert in runtime, and when I released this big batch of changes I accidentally released some work in progress code that was not complete.

But now I moved back up to I20051116-1332 and I cannot seem to reproduce. I think this is core.resources problem. I also moved back to last week I-Build and my workspace came back. However, I still get these exceptions when I tried again to switch on I20051116-1332 after... Note that I can open a brand new workspace or a real simple old one (just one project Test in it with one class Test...). But I get these exceptions with all my other workspaces (at least all o.e.jdt.core* projects loaded in it).
I think you will get the failure when a workspace contains a project that is outside the default location... I will work on a fix/patch. Is there any possible workaround waiting for this patch (except than remove external project of course...)?
I suggest staying on the previous integration build until I have a patch. *** Bug 116874 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I have released the fix to HEAD. A patch that works on any I-build from this week is available here:
http://eclipse.org/eclipse/platform-core/downloads.html#patches
Don't forget to restart with -clean after dropping the patch in your plugins directory. Thanks to our new qualified version numbers it is not necessary to delete the old jar first. I will also send a note to platform-releng-dev. Marking fixed. And, sorry for the headaches this probably caused. I renamed the "Assert" class in core.resources to prevent a collision with the new Assert in runtime, and when I released this big batch of changes I accidentally released some work in progress code that was not complete.

Bug.Summery: The maven provider doesn't appear to respect specific versionSelector and a 'PERFECT' matchrule
Bug.WithStack: In core, the cspex for log4j has been set to force 1.2.9 through a PERFECT matchrule - but the maven provider still comes up with 1.2.12 Actually, all providers made incorrect decisions when a match higher then the requested one was found. The rule was simply ignored when that happened. .
Bug.WithOutStack: In core, the cspex for log4j has been set to force 1.2.9 through a PERFECT matchrule - but the maven provider still comes up with 1.2.12 Actually, all providers made incorrect decisions when a match higher then the requested one was found. The rule was simply ignored when that happened. .

Bug.Summery: Output to System.out ceases to appear when logging with out-trapping is applied
Bug.WithStack: It appears that something has changed in Log4j 1.2.12 vs 1.2.9. As a temporary solution we'll force core to bring in 1.2.9 while we investigate the cause. Alas, bug #116852 prevents this. Cool doh, this should of course stay open until we figured out why 1.2.12 causes problems... As expected, Log4j 1.2.12 had changed strategy vs 1.2.9 for writing to System.out/err. New ConsoleAppender subclass now used that works with both versions (and above, I hope) .
Bug.WithOutStack: It appears that something has changed in Log4j 1.2.12 vs 1.2.9. As a temporary solution we'll force core to bring in 1.2.9 while we investigate the cause. Alas, bug #116852 prevents this. Cool doh, this should of course stay open until we figured out why 1.2.12 causes problems... As expected, Log4j 1.2.12 had changed strategy vs 1.2.9 for writing to System.out/err. New ConsoleAppender subclass now used that works with both versions (and above, I hope) .

Bug.Summery: StyledText with SWT.WRAP cuts last character of wrapped line

source_code.code: final Font font = new Font (display, "Tahoma", 8, SWT.NORMAL);

Lines.Line: - CustomControlExample, StyledText, WinXP default font (Tahoma Regular 8)
- select 50 X 50
- select SWT.WRAP
- set text to "a/Path/to/A.java" (no quotes)
-> the character "A" is cut off; should appear on second line

Bug.WithStack:
I20051116-1332
- CustomControlExample, StyledText, WinXP default font (Tahoma Regular 8) - select 50 X 50 - select SWT.WRAP - set text to "a/Path/to/A.java" (no quotes) -> the character "A" is cut off; should appear on second line
This is very annoying in the Details Pane of debug's Variables view. Created attachment 30130 Screenshot Bug in TextLayout:
final Display display = new Display(); Shell shell = new Shell(display); final Font font = new Font (display, "Tahoma", 8, SWT.NORMAL); shell.addListener(SWT.Paint, new Listener() { public void handleEvent(Event event) { TextLayout layout = new TextLayout(display); layout.setFont(font); layout.setText ("a/Path/to/A.java"); layout.setWidth(50); layout.draw(event.gc, 10, 10); event.gc.drawRectangle(10, 10, 50, 50); layout.dispose(); } }); shell.open(); while (!shell.isDisposed()) { if (!display.readAndDispatch()) display.sleep(); } font.dispose (); display.dispose ();
Is there any known workaround for this issue? I am seeing this in a few places within an RCP app that I am working on, and I don't know of a workaround for it. When the window the StyledText is in is resized, the wrapping suddenly snaps into place, but I'm not sure about a programmatic way of fixing the issue. To ensure that we're not duplicating effort... I debugged this today and am working on a patch. The issue is that there's a flag on a run that states if the run is to have a line break. When set this is assumed to be at the beginning of the run. But when calculating widths it's applied at the end of the run. In the example from comment 2 the run with the line break is the 'A'. The issue is in the loop starting on line 370 in TextLayout. I couldn't find documentation stating whether the line break is to be applied at the end or the beginning. I'm assuming that it should be applied at the beginning.
Here's the info gathered for the comment 2 snippet. (I stopped with my debugging after the 'A'.)
A = character B = Index C = Run Index D = Run Width E = Run lineBreak
A B C D E = = = = = a 0 0 6 0 / 1 1 4 0 P 2 2 22 0 a 3 0 t 4 0 h 5 0 / 6 3 4 0 t 7 4 10 0 o 8 0 / 9 5 4 0 A 10 6 7 1 . j a v a
I'll try to have a patch in the next couple of days. Hopefully this will be able to go in 3.3.1 as well. Created attachment 77483 TextLayout - HEAD patch Created attachment 77484 TextLayout - 3_3_maintenance patch I've attached patches for both HEAD and the 3.3 maintenance stream. I didn't see any existing tests for TextLayout. I would like to write some but I'm out of time on this. Also I tried running the existing tests and I get failures about invalid thread access for the basic tests that have nothing to do with TextLayout. If I had more time I'd diagnose this but I just don't have it. Hopefully someone can take this the rest of the way.
With this patch the snippet from comment 2 now renders correctly and the quick brown fox still jumps over the lazy dog in the custom control example.
(In reply to comment #4) > The issue is in the loop starting on line 370 in TextLayout. I couldn't find > documentation stating whether the line break is to be applied at the end or the > beginning. I'm assuming that it should be applied at the beginning.
This statement turned out to be incorrect. LineBreak is meant to be applied at the end of the run. Thanks for patch, I finally had the time to review it. (I'm actually surprised that somelse was able to understand the messy code in computeRuns()).
I understood the patch. The only that I don't agree is this line: ---- i = firstIndice - 1; run = allRuns[i]; start = run.start; <- This line ----
start is a index relative to the start of the run. run.start is start index of the run relative to the entire text.
I think the right code is: i = firstIndice - 1; run = allRuns[i]; start = run.length - 1;
Do you know of any reason why that would be a problem ?
(In reply to comment #8) > start is a index relative to the start of the run. > run.start is start index of the run relative to the entire text. > > I think the right code is: > i = firstIndice - 1; > run = allRuns[i]; > start = run.length - 1; > > Do you know of any reason why that would be a problem ?
That definitely looks wrong now that you mention it. But with it being run.length - 1 it looks like it will get into the while that follows (starting around line 331). The while loop will just run once and it will be incremented to being run.length. Should it just be run.length to begin with? Fixed in HEAD.
I used 'start = run.length;'
Sorry, I don't plan to backport this to 3.3.1. This is a low priority bug. (In reply to comment #10) > Sorry, I don't plan to backport this to 3.3.1. This is a low priority bug. > Except for the folks getting yelled at because their text is getting cut off all of a sudden, just because of a version upgrade. If this isn't getting back-ported, is there at least a workaround for it? If we put together a corrected patch for the 3.3.1 codebase could we get it back-ported? The fix is good.
We are only backporting critical fixes to 3.3.1 and I don't think this is critical since the case where wrapping fails doesn't happen very often.
--- I've added Brad Reynolds to our contributors list. Thank you for the fix! http://www.eclipse.org/swt/contributors.txt

--- I've added Brad Reynolds to our contributors list. Thank you for the fix! http://www.eclipse.org/swt/contributors.txt

Bug.Summery: Classpath Dependancies vs J2EE Dependancies (need to be clear/clean)
Bug.WithStack:
I think that Eclipse should make a clear distinction between:
classpath dependancies - Things not provided by the application/project but expected of the runtime by the application/project at deployment. This has the same meaning for non-container projects and the build path is already geared up this way as it stands.
J2EE dependancies - Things that are needed by the application/project to copy inside the J2EE component to create the project in deployable form.
So to remove any confusion everything under the Properties -> J2EE dependancies should only be related to J2EE dependancies never classpath dependancies.
The reason why I think its confusing is that the "Add External JARs" and "Add Variable" buttons under "J2EE Module Dependancies" -> "Web Libraries" actually configure the "classpath dependancies" not the "J2EE dependancies" as per my definions above.
Related bug reports: bug #116783 bug #116489 I think the whole UI needs some kind of rework. Currently it is difficult to setup. There should be a better editor for this (maybe as part of bug 133359).
People should not need to think different when using WTP. WTP should adapt to them. For example, let them continue to use the Build Path property page for configuring the classpath of their projects. Then, provide an editor for selecting which JARs or projects of the classpath should be deployed to the server. This editor could also allow to define additional elements to deploy.
The editor will track changes to the classpath and as soon as a user adds a new classpath element, it will attach a warning or error marker to the project telling the developer that he still has to configure if this element should be deployed to the server. Some review/consolidation of the J2EE module dependencies/Java build path may be motivated for 2.0
Chuck: would be good to get your thoughts here given scope/impact and overlap with other bugzillas *** Bug 126825 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Note: the fix for https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=128851 gets things started down this path and will ultimately a full detangling of the .classpath and component files. The changes for https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=128851 are in 2.0 M6; so, you can now manage library, var and cp container entries via the Java Build Path UI and then use the J2EE Module Dependencies UI to select the subset that should be published/exported.
Project and src path entries are still mananged entirely via the component file/J2EE Module Dependencies UI so I'll leave this open and set the target to 3.0 as a tentative timeframe during which we can attempt to rationalize handling of these other items. I still think there is a need for both properties, but the J2EE Dep page needs to be more transparent to any classpath changes that may occur when adding/removing dependencies.
Need to remove any overlap in function (MANIFEST changes do nake classpath entries dynamicaly with the new dynamic containers) See discussion in https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=138648 Please see the following wiki page (http://wiki.eclipse.org/Web_Tools_Platform_Release_3.0_Requirements/JavaCPvsJavaEEModDeps) for initial design thoughts on how we can leverage the new (in 2.0) classpath entry publish/export support to overhaul the management of the Java classpath and Java EE module dependencies in the 3.0 timeframe.
This is also linked into the WTP 3.0 reqs wiki and I'll post something on the dev list soon as well - once folks have a chance to digest, we can try to schedule a call to gather feedback/discuss and refine.
*** Bug 138648 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** There's a lot of discussion in this bug, bug 138648 and the WIKI on this issue, I would like to clarify if this RFE is intended to cover the following scenarios:
- When a Web project that depends on a Java utility projects is published on a server, would there be a programmatic way to specify which additonal JARs on the Java utility project's build path need to be deployed with the WAR?
(In reply to comment #10) > There's a lot of discussion in this bug, bug 138648 and the WIKI on this issue, > I would like to clarify if this RFE is intended to cover the following > scenarios: > > - When a Web project that depends on a Java utility projects is published on a > server, would there be a programmatic way to specify which additonal JARs on > the Java utility project's build path need to be deployed with the WAR? > hi Kathy,
That can be accomplished now (i.e. in 2.0) by adding the publish/export classpath attribute to the library cp entries in the utility project that are associated with the JARs you want deployed.
Adding the attribute programmatically can be accomplished via API in the org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.classpathdep package (see UpdateClasspathAttributeUtil.addDependencyAttribute()).
Adding the attribute via the UI is a bit awkward in 2.0.x/3.0 since the J2EE Module Dependencies UI is not displayed for utility projects that are referenced just by dynamic web projects; the way to accomplish this now via the UI is by using the QuickFix on the warning that is generated for that cp entry in the utility project (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=184094 covers adding full UI support).
For standalone dynamic web projects or projects referenced by an EAR, the valid cp entries are listed in the J2EE Module Dependencies UI as potential dependencies (w/ a different icon) and one can simply select/deselect the entry to add/remove the attribute.
See https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=185176 for more details on how this all works currently.
-Rob
The required support for project cp entries is not going to make 3.0 (due to a number of risk/complexity issues) so need to push this enhancement out of the committed set as well. removed plan from keywords.... future enhancement Assigning to Carl for evaluation

Bug.Summery: java code formatter problem with switch statements and comments
Need some refactoring API in JDT/Core
Bug.WithStack:
For M4 we are adding support to rename type that allows updating declared names which are similar to the type to be renamed. If this new support is enabled an additional participant has to be loaded and additional arguments have to be apssed to the participant. These arguments have to be Java specific since they refer to the additional elements updated by the refactoring.
Up to now a refactoring participant listening to Java refactoring only need a dependency to ltk.core and jdt.core not to jdt.ui. That's why I would like to see the API hosted in core not in ui. Otherwise we might force an existing core plug-in to add a reference to jdt.ui Created attachment 30134 A patch containing the necessary modifications and the new code. Philippe, can you please have a look and decide whether core is willing to host that code. We do not use 'assert' in our code. Do we really need a separate source folder for this ? We should also add these new API to the javadoc generation if we put them in a separate source folder. I made it a separate source folder to be consistent with the rest of the structure of the core plug-in. However, I am fully open to not have it.
Are you using IllegalArgumentException instead ? Dirk will rethink of forking a separate plugin, and get back to us. We agreed that adding these types in core would be the fallback solution. Likely, more JDT refactoring APIs would end up in the same area, so a 'refactoring' source folder would be preferrable if any. We use 'IllegalArgumentException' in cases (rare) or nothing, and let the code die (RuntimeException later on). I discussed the idea of an additional problem in ZRH and we like it. I will rethink over the weekend and if I still think it is the right thing to do I will write a corresponding proposal. What will code into the corext is the whole refactoring, code manipulation (source operations), quick fix, clean up, ...
This seems obsolote with the addition of the new plugin org.eclipse.jdt.core.manipulation. yes, this is solved now with the new plugin.

What will code into the corext is the whole refactoring, code manipulation (source operations), quick fix, clean up, ...

Bug.Summery: JavaJet uses the workbench defaults to compile a JavaJet
Bug.WithStack:
If a User changes the defaults to a 1.5 compiance on the whole workbench, VE will use it to compile the template. This will cause a problem, if the IDE runs with a 1.4 JRE.
Given the simplicity of the template, and the fact that VE does not support 1.5 syntax yet, force the compile to use a 1.4 comliance when compiling a JavaJet. Released to CVS Closing
Bug.WithOutStack:
If a User changes the defaults to a 1.5 compiance on the whole workbench, VE will use it to compile the template. This will cause a problem, if the IDE runs with a 1.4 JRE.
Given the simplicity of the template, and the fact that VE does not support 1.5 syntax yet, force the compile to use a 1.4 comliance when compiling a JavaJet. Released to CVS Closing

Bug.Summery: Validation: all the GenFeatures in GenModel should be isReferenceType()

Lines.Line: - NodeMapping.getContainmentFeature()
- ChildNodeMapping.getDomainChildrenFeature()
- LinkMapping.getContainmentFeature()
- LinkMapping.getLinkMetaFeature()

Bug.WithStack:
For now we allow to specify only EReference instances as "structural" properties of mapping model:
- NodeMapping.getContainmentFeature() - ChildNodeMapping.getDomainChildrenFeature() - LinkMapping.getContainmentFeature() - LinkMapping.getLinkMetaFeature()
These properties will be propagated into the .gmfgen model. But, in this model there some other GenFeature instances could be specified by user instead of the generated "correct" one. As a result, .gmfgen model could become invalid.
While validating .gmfgen we should check that for all the GenFeatures specified as a corresponding properties in the model .isReferenceType() return true.
This request is not so important since not all the users will change .gmfgen model manually, but to complete validation process we probably should cover it too. In terms of current .gmfgen model these constraints looks like:
context TypeModelFacet inv: containmentMetaFeature.ecoreFeature.oclIsKindOf(ecore::EReference)
context TypeLinkModelFacet inv: targetMetaFeature.ecoreFeature.oclIsKindOf(ecore::EReference)
context FeatureModelFacet inv: metaFeature.ecoreFeature.oclIsKindOf(ecore::EReference)
Seems like partually these constraints are alredy checked now. Moving to the next version Marked as enhancement as it represents an extension of the current validation and does not prevent anything from functioning. Introducing this error would require manual modification of the GenModel by the user. Moving to version 2.0.0 Bulk update, descoping from 2.0 Currently, TypeLinkModelFacet#sourceMetaFeature and targetMetaFeature miss constraint, as well as FeatureLinkModelFacet#metaFeature. Rest are ok. [GMF Restructure] Bug 319140 : product GMF and component Generation was the original product and component for this bug

context FeatureModelFacet inv: metaFeature.ecoreFeature.oclIsKindOf(ecore::EReference)

Bug.Summery: [WorkingSets] Renamed working set appears with old name
Bug.WithStack: With build I20051116-1332, I renamed a working set in the packages explorer when the view was in working set mode. When I tried to select working sets in other views (Java Projects view and Navigator) the set appeared under the old name. Choosing to edit the set opened a dialog which had the proper name. Fix in HEAD. Label attribute now follows name attribute until a setLabel() call differentiates the two. Verified in I20051213-0010
Bug.WithOutStack: With build I20051116-1332, I renamed a working set in the packages explorer when the view was in working set mode. When I tried to select working sets in other views (Java Projects view and Navigator) the set appeared under the old name. Choosing to edit the set opened a dialog which had the proper name. Fix in HEAD. Label attribute now follows name attribute until a setLabel() call differentiates the two. Verified in I20051213-0010

Bug.Summery: Module can not be targetted to runtime
Bug.WithStack:
Module can not be targeted to a runtime if the runtime does not support the latest (or all) versions of the module type. I have noticed this when trying to create a web module and target JBoss 3.2.3. I also have the same result for weblogic 8.1 I did some investigation, this related to wizards asking for runtimes with the greatest facet version number. I noticed that the default value for IFacetDataModelProperties.FACET_VERSION is the latest version of the facet.(FacetInstallDataModelProvider line 45) This makes it impossible to create dynamic web projects that does not support the latest facet version. Currently we default the latest version, which does filterout the runtimes that don't suport this version. I am dupping this against the bug that will default the version based on the initial runtime selected if any.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 116699 *** This bug was moved to 'closed' state, since it is so old and since it is a dup, worksforme, invalid bug that its unlikely to still be useful or need further attention. Feel free to re-open, or open a new bug, if this semi-automatic processing was done in error.
