Module can not be targeted to a runtime if the runtime does not support the latest (or all) versions of the module type. I have noticed this when trying to create a web module and target JBoss 3.2.3. I also have the same result for weblogic 8.1 I did some investigation, this related to wizards asking for runtimes with the greatest facet version number. I noticed that the default value for IFacetDataModelProperties.FACET_VERSION is the latest version of the facet.(FacetInstallDataModelProvider line 45) This makes it impossible to create dynamic web projects that does not support the latest facet version. Currently we default the latest version, which does filterout the runtimes that don't suport this version. I am dupping this against the bug that will default the version based on the initial runtime selected if any.

Bug.Summery: Mylar classpath broken when using alt install locations in e3.1.1

Lines.Line: 1. Use mylar update site for e3.1 installing on Eclipse 3.1.1
2. When prompted select new installation target outside of the normal eclipse
plugin directory (i.e. C:\Java\eclipse-plugins_3.1.1\Mylar_Eclipse_3.1x was used)
3. Install, restart
4. Attempt to show any of the Mylar views you'll see an error similar to the
following (this being for ActiveHierarchyView):
"Unable to Create View: Plug-in org.eclipse.mylar.java was unable to load class
org.eclipse.mylar.java.ui.views.ActiveHierarchyView."
Error Details:

Bug.WithStack:
Steps used to create problem:
1. Use mylar update site for e3.1 installing on Eclipse 3.1.1

Root exception: java.lang.UnsupportedClassVersionError: org/eclipse/mylar/java/MylarJavaPlugin (Unsupported major.minor version 49.0) at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass0(Native Method) at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass(ClassLoader.java:537)
Which indicates that Mylar is attempting to load in a 1.4 VM. See the following FAQ entry for how to address this: http://eclipse.org/mylar/doc/faq.html#install-failure
Also, I suggest that you update to 0.4.5 this evening, possibly before trying to reinstall again, because the log indicated some update connection failures so there is a (small) chance that not all the plug-ins downloaded successfully. If you still see failures after trying that please reopen.

Bug.Summery: [WorkbenchLauncher] Extra white pixels on the left and right of the progress bar
Bug.WithStack:
I20051115-0800
There are some extra white pixels on either side of the progress bar and it appears that the bar is not flush with the bottom of the splash. Will attach a screencap. Created attachment 30137 Screencap If this white is not part of the progress bar then the splash should show through, moving to SWT to see what the code is doing on the Mac, is this one pixel of the parent for the progress bar showing through? Kim, could you snap another progress bar in a different context? I wonder if the white on left right and bottom exists elsewhere? Created attachment 30782 Progress View
Here are a couple living in the progress view. No white pixels... this is similar to bug 114640 Is Kim right that the progress bars elsewhere don't seem to have the extra white pixel? The extra white pixels on the sides is just the shadow of the prograss bar. It does happen in the screenshot from comment#4 also, but it is less visible because the background is grey (not blue) which makes it harder to see. There is nothing that can be done to change this.
The bottom of the progress bar is not flushed to the bottom of the window because the progress bar on Mac has a fixed height (12 pixels). It does not get bigger than that. This should be easy to fix now that the splash is done with SWT. This should no longer be an issue.

Bug.Summery: Need ability to write DDL with .ddl extension
Bug.WithStack: The current method for writing DDL files via RTEHelper always force the filename to have a .sql extension. We need the ability to have a .ddl extension. Created attachment 30165 patch 1 Created attachment 30166 Patch 2 Applied patches on November 17, 2005. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack: The current method for writing DDL files via RTEHelper always force the filename to have a .sql extension. We need the ability to have a .ddl extension. Created attachment 30165 patch 1 Created attachment 30166 Patch 2 Applied patches on November 17, 2005. Verified.

Bug.Summery: Change to MANIFEST.MF Files has Broken Eclipse 3.1.1 Clients
Bug.WithStack: The MANIFEST.MF files must retain the deprecated "Eclipse-AutoStart: true" setting rather than the new eclipse 3.2 "Eclipse-LazyStart: true" setting or else Eclipse 3.1.1 clients will be broken at runtime. Reverted to AutoStart for the 1.0M3 build, after which we will remove this deprecated usage and dependency on the 3.1.x platform. [GMF Restructure] Bug 319140 : product GMF and component Releng was the original product and component for this bug
Bug.WithOutStack: The MANIFEST.MF files must retain the deprecated "Eclipse-AutoStart: true" setting rather than the new eclipse 3.2 "Eclipse-LazyStart: true" setting or else Eclipse 3.1.1 clients will be broken at runtime. Reverted to AutoStart for the 1.0M3 build, after which we will remove this deprecated usage and dependency on the 3.1.x platform. [GMF Restructure] Bug 319140 : product GMF and component Releng was the original product and component for this bug

Bug.Summery: detect when make version is not suitable for managed make builds

Lines.Line: (a) failures due to non GNU make's
(b) failures due to out-of-date versions of GNU Make
for example, the version shipped from
http://unxutils.sourceforge.net/ is 3.78.1. This version seems to erroneously
report that the compiler/linker executables could not be
found when they are on the path (using GNU Make 3.80 solve this)
one possiblity might be to detect when a build fails, execute "make -v" and
parse the output looking for GNU and a version number. This would be brittle
in both the output of the make command, and the customizability of the make
command. The code could only report to the user if it could positively detect
that the make command being used was not compatible with the make files being
generated, otherwise it could remain silent?
having had a quick first look at the source code, the place that I think this
could be fixed would be
org.eclipse.cdt.managedbuilder.internal.core.GeneratedMakefileBuilder.java
however, this is more general than the place where GNU Make becomes a
dependency (GnuMakefileGenerator). Maybe to properly treat this, a
IManagedBuilderMakefileGenerator2 interface would need creating with a
callback for diagnosing build failure, or preemptively checking that the make
tool is compatible with the generated make files (although care would be
needed to avoid false negatives)
Hi Andrew,
I agree this should be fixed.
I知 not sure that extending the buildfile generator is the best approach, since
the tool-chain/tool/builder support info might be needed not only while makefile
generation/building, but also while project creation, or when the project build
properties are being displayed/edited, etc.
I've got the following proposal for fixing this:
Currently there is the isSupported mechanism that specifies the
support/unsupport status on the tool-chain level. So currently an ISV can
implement the isSupported call-back that would check for the builder version and
specify that the tool-chain is not supported. This is not really informative for
the user, since the user might need to know the exact reason why the tool-chain
is not supported. More than that, in the future there will be the possibility to
change tools in the tool-chain thus making the tool-chain level isSupported
mechanism work incorrectly for the tool-chain with substituted tools.
We could provide the capability to specify a per-tool/builder isSupported
call-back, which will allow the isSupported mechanism function properly for the
tool-chains with substituted tools and also will provide more valuable and
informative information for the user.
The IToolChain.isSupported method in this case will query all its tools and a
builder for the support status (along with the tool-chain isSupported callback
if present) and will return the appropriate support status.
What do others think?
Thanks,
Mikhail
Hi Mikhail,
That sounds interesting, but we'll have to think about when it is appropriate
to display different types of error messages. For example, if the make version
is out of date, do we allow the user to create a project with the tool-chain or
not? Do we give an error message at project creation or when the user tries to
build the project?
I think that we will also need to expand the isSupported interface to allow the
callee to pass back a message describing why the tool/toolchain/etc is not
supported - to display to the user in certain cases. We also need to consider
which messages to display only once per CDT session, since isSupported is
called for many reasons.
I think we need a detailed analysis of when isSupported is called now, and when
it is appropriate to return certain types of error messages. We may need
several different methods in the isSupported interface.
Leo
I agree with Leo.
(In reply to comment #3)
Hi Leo,
> Hi Mikhail,
> That sounds interesting, but we'll have to think about when it is appropriate
> to display different types of error messages. For example, if the make version
> is out of date, do we allow the user to create a project with the tool-chain or
> not?
My opinion is that we should hide by default all project-types/configurations
that will not build. If the builder is not supported, the project will not build
in anyway, so I suppose we should hide project-types/configurations with builder
unsupported.
>Do we give an error message at project creation or when the user tries to
> build the project?
I suppose that displaying some informative information could be useful both
while project creation and while building, so I think the
project-type/configuration selection page of the new project wizard could
contain some status bar that would provide the user some more detailed
information regarding project-type/configuration support status.
> I think that we will also need to expand the isSupported interface to allow the
> callee to pass back a message describing why the tool/toolchain/etc is not
> supported - to display to the user in certain cases.
I agree. We should also support the "default behavior", when no message is
provided, e.g. MBS might generate the following message:
"The following tools are not supported for this configuration: <tool-name1>, …
,<tool-name-N>"
> We also need to consider
> which messages to display only once per CDT session, since isSupported is
> called for many reasons.
Currently the isSupported status is queried:
1. when creating a new project - to display only supported
project-types/configurations by default.
2. when the project is being built - to display the warning message in case the
project is unsupported
3. when the build property page is displayed – to display a warning message in
the status bar in case the currently selected configuration is unsupported
4. when selecting the default configuration at the project creation – to select
the supported configuration
5. In the "Create Configuration" dialog to display/hide unsupported
configurations in the "Copy settings from" list.
I don’t think we need to change all the above queries to be only once per CDT
session.
Do you think we need to check and display the support status somewhere else once
pre CDT session?
> I think we need a detailed analysis of when isSupported is called now, and when
> it is appropriate to return certain types of error messages.
I agree.
>We may need
> several different methods in the isSupported interface.
Looking at the way the isSupported is used currently, I suppose we might need
only to extend the isSupported to return some status object instead of Boolean
value.
The status might contain:
- the "support" status that might specify the following:
i. the tool/tool-chain is supported
ii. the tool/tool-chain is not supported
- for the tool-chain: the list of IDs of the unsupported tools/builder.
- the human-readable string representing the reason why the tool/tool-chain is
unsupported.
1. when creating a new project - to display only supported
project-types/configurations by default.
2. when the project is being built - to display the warning message in case the
project is unsupported
3. when the build property page is displayed – to display a warning message in
the status bar in case the currently selected configuration is unsupported
4. when selecting the default configuration at the project creation – to select
the supported configuration
5. In the "Create Configuration" dialog to display/hide unsupported
configurations in the "Copy settings from" list.
(1) tool/toolchain is not supported because of wrong platform (os/arch). I
realize the line is fuzzy here around what constitutes and os/arch however..
(2) tool/toolchain is not supported because it is not installed (or present,
or maybe licensed?)
(3) tool/toolchain is present,licensed but the builder it relies upon cannot
function
1. The tool-chain MBS integration might not exist or might not be properly
installed into Eclipse. I can't think of any help that the MBS can give in
this case since it knows nothing about the tool-chain. One side note - MBS
should display a helpful message dialog when the user tries to create a project
and there are no (zero) supported tool-chains. I think it will currently just
display an empty list which is not good.
2. The tool-chain integration is present, but the tool-chain is not supported
on the host platform. The current MBS behavior, for project creation, is to
not display the tool-chain's project-types by default, but to display them if
the user selects to show all project-types. This seems like reasonable
behavior. I'd rather not confuse the user by automatically displaying choices
that they are less likely to want to select. Note that the current
implementation calls isSupported() before checking for the OS and Architecture
matches - this seems like it may be backwards.
3. The tool-chain integration is present and is supported on the current host,
but the tool-chain isn't installed (or can't be found). This requires tool-
chain specific logic which is why we have the current isSupported() callback.
The current MBS behavior, for project creation, is to not display the tool-
chain's project-types by default, but to display them if the user selects to
show all project-types. This seems like reasonable behavior *if* the user
wasn't expecting to use that tool-chain anyway. But if they did expect to be
able to use that tool-chain, they probably won't understand why the project-
types are not displayed by default. Maybe we should have a "Show Problems"
button, or a "Problems List" at the bottom, on the project-type selection
dialog that explains why tool-chains are being excluded from the list. The
isSupported mechanism needs to provide a way for the tool-chain code to return
its explanation of what is wrong, and, as Mikhail points out, we also need
default messages. The other, less likey, case here might be that the user has
done some sort of custom installation and set up environment variables, etc. to
make the tool-chain work, but the tool-chain isSupported code doesn't know
about it and so returns that the tool-chain is not installed. Do we need some
way to allow the user to override the decision?
4. The tool-chain integration is present, is supported on the current host,
and is installed, but the tool-chain knows that the build will fail for some
reason, including:
- Not licensed
- Wrong version of some component
- The user has edited the tool-chain and added a tool that won't work for one
of the reasons discussed above. Mikhail's suggestion of adding the isSupported
mechanism to Tool and Builder helps in this case.
Andrew's suggestion of marking the project with an error marker and disabling
building sounds good in this case.
- Not licensed
- Wrong version of some component
- The user has edited the tool-chain and added a tool that won't work for one
of the reasons discussed above. Mikhail's suggestion of adding the isSupported
mechanism to Tool and Builder helps in this case.
Andrew's suggestion of marking the project with an error marker and disabling
building sounds good in this case.

Bug.WithStack:
hi,
I've been showing CDT to a few people and have seen how many of them are bitten by not having a correct version of make on the path (when using the managed build system). In terms of out-of-the-box experience it would be great if these common failure cases could be detected.
I've seen both (a) failures due to non GNU make's (b) failures due to out-of-date versions of GNU Make for example, the version shipped from http://unxutils.sourceforge.net/ is 3.78.1. This version seems to erroneously report that the compiler/linker executables could not be found when they are on the path (using GNU Make 3.80 solve this)
one possiblity might be to detect when a build fails, execute "make -v" and parse the output looking for GNU and a version number. This would be brittle in both the output of the make command, and the customizability of the make command. The code could only report to the user if it could positively detect that the make command being used was not compatible with the make files being generated, otherwise it could remain silent? having had a quick first look at the source code, the place that I think this could be fixed would be org.eclipse.cdt.managedbuilder.internal.core.GeneratedMakefileBuilder.java
however, this is more general than the place where GNU Make becomes a dependency (GnuMakefileGenerator). Maybe to properly treat this, a IManagedBuilderMakefileGenerator2 interface would need creating with a callback for diagnosing build failure, or preemptively checking that the make tool is compatible with the generated make files (although care would be needed to avoid false negatives)
Hi Andrew,
I agree this should be fixed. I知 not sure that extending the buildfile generator is the best approach, since the tool-chain/tool/builder support info might be needed not only while makefile generation/building, but also while project creation, or when the project build properties are being displayed/edited, etc.
I've got the following proposal for fixing this:
Currently there is the isSupported mechanism that specifies the support/unsupport status on the tool-chain level. So currently an ISV can implement the isSupported call-back that would check for the builder version and specify that the tool-chain is not supported. This is not really informative for the user, since the user might need to know the exact reason why the tool-chain is not supported. More than that, in the future there will be the possibility to change tools in the tool-chain thus making the tool-chain level isSupported mechanism work incorrectly for the tool-chain with substituted tools. We could provide the capability to specify a per-tool/builder isSupported call-back, which will allow the isSupported mechanism function properly for the tool-chains with substituted tools and also will provide more valuable and informative information for the user. The IToolChain.isSupported method in this case will query all its tools and a builder for the support status (along with the tool-chain isSupported callback if present) and will return the appropriate support status.
What do others think?
Thanks, Mikhail Hi Mikhail,
That sounds interesting, but we'll have to think about when it is appropriate to display different types of error messages. For example, if the make version is out of date, do we allow the user to create a project with the tool-chain or not? Do we give an error message at project creation or when the user tries to build the project?
I think that we will also need to expand the isSupported interface to allow the callee to pass back a message describing why the tool/toolchain/etc is not supported - to display to the user in certain cases. We also need to consider which messages to display only once per CDT session, since isSupported is called for many reasons.
I think we need a detailed analysis of when isSupported is called now, and when it is appropriate to return certain types of error messages. We may need several different methods in the isSupported interface.
Leo I agree with Leo. (In reply to comment #3) Hi Leo,
> Hi Mikhail, > > That sounds interesting, but we'll have to think about when it is appropriate > to display different types of error messages. For example, if the make version > is out of date, do we allow the user to create a project with the tool-chain or > not? > > I think that we will also need to expand the isSupported interface to allow the > callee to pass back a message describing why the tool/toolchain/etc is not > supported - to display to the user in certain cases. I agree. We should also support the "default behavior", when no message is provided, e.g. MBS might generate the following message: "The following tools are not supported for this configuration: <tool-name1>, … ,<tool-name-N>"

In the "Create Configuration" dialog to display/hide unsupported configurations in the "Copy settings from" list.
I don’t think we need to change all the above queries to be only once per CDT session. Do you think we need to check and display the support status somewhere else once pre CDT session?
> > I think we need a detailed analysis of when isSupported is called now, and when > it is appropriate to return certain types of error messages. I agree.
>We may need > several different methods in the isSupported interface. Looking at the way the isSupported is used currently, I suppose we might need only to extend the isSupported to return some status object instead of Boolean value. The status might contain: - the "support" status that might specify the following: i. the tool/tool-chain is supported ii. the tool/tool-chain is not supported - for the tool-chain: the list of IDs of the unsupported tools/builder. - the human-readable string representing the reason why the tool/tool-chain is unsupported.

> > Leo
Regards, Mikhail
I would say hiding project types that won't build is not a good behaviour in the case where a user gets a fresh copy of eclipse, cdt and a toolchain that uses the managed build system - as when they go to start a new project, they might get a wizard that doesn't allow them to create one, because no builder is supported.
Some scenarios might be (1) tool/toolchain is not supported because of wrong platform (os/arch). I realize the line is fuzzy here around what constitutes and os/arch however.. (2) tool/toolchain is not supported because it is not installed (or present, or maybe licensed?) (3) tool/toolchain is present,licensed but the builder it relies upon cannot function
How about allowing project creation in all of the above, but subsequently marking the project with an error marker and disabling building?
The explanation would appear as the description of a high priority Problem. This is analogous to how Java Projects refuse to build until all of their project references are present.
Andrew and Mikhail,
You have some interesting ideas. Let me try to summarize what I'm thinking at the moment - of course, that could change with further discussion.
There are a few different "failure points" where the user might reasonably expect that their tool-chain will work in the MBS and it doesn't:
1. The tool-chain MBS integration might not exist or might not be properly installed into Eclipse. I can't think of any help that the MBS can give in this case since it knows nothing about the tool-chain. One side note - MBS should display a helpful message dialog when the user tries to create a project and there are no (zero) supported tool-chains. I think it will currently just display an empty list which is not good.
2. The tool-chain integration is present, but the tool-chain is not supported on the host platform. The current MBS behavior, for project creation, is to not display the tool-chain's project-types by default, but to display them if the user selects to show all project-types. This seems like reasonable behavior. I'd rather not confuse the user by automatically displaying choices that they are less likely to want to select. Note that the current implementation calls isSupported() before checking for the OS and Architecture matches - this seems like it may be backwards.
3. The tool-chain integration is present and is supported on the current host, but the tool-chain isn't installed (or can't be found). This requires tool- chain specific logic which is why we have the current isSupported() callback. The current MBS behavior, for project creation, is to not display the tool- chain's project-types by default, but to display them if the user selects to show all project-types. This seems like reasonable behavior *if* the user wasn't expecting to use that tool-chain anyway. But if they did expect to be able to use that tool-chain, they probably won't understand why the project- types are not displayed by default. Maybe we should have a "Show Problems" button, or a "Problems List" at the bottom, on the project-type selection dialog that explains why tool-chains are being excluded from the list. The isSupported mechanism needs to provide a way for the tool-chain code to return its explanation of what is wrong, and, as Mikhail points out, we also need default messages. The other, less likey, case here might be that the user has done some sort of custom installation and set up environment variables, etc. to make the tool-chain work, but the tool-chain isSupported code doesn't know about it and so returns that the tool-chain is not installed. Do we need some way to allow the user to override the decision?
4. The tool-chain integration is present, is supported on the current host, and is installed, but the tool-chain knows that the build will fail for some reason, including: - Not licensed - Wrong version of some component - The user has edited the tool-chain and added a tool that won't work for one of the reasons discussed above. Mikhail's suggestion of adding the isSupported mechanism to Tool and Builder helps in this case. Andrew's suggestion of marking the project with an error marker and disabling building sounds good in this case.
Should we break up the current isSupported() method into isInstalled() and canBuild() methods that return a status such as Mikhail suggests?
Regards, Leo (In reply to comment #7)
Leo, Andrew,
> There are a few different "failure points" where the user might reasonably > expect that their tool-chain will work in the MBS and it doesn't: > > 1. The tool-chain MBS integration might not exist or might not be properly > installed into Eclipse. I can't think of any help that the MBS can give in > this case since it knows nothing about the tool-chain. One side note - MBS > should display a helpful message dialog when the user tries to create a project > and there are no (zero) supported tool-chains. I think it will currently just > display an empty list which is not good. I agree.
> 2. The tool-chain integration is present, but the tool-chain is not supported > on the host platform. The current MBS behavior, for project creation, is to > not display the tool-chain's project-types by default, but to display them if > the user selects to show all project-types. This seems like reasonable > behavior. I'd rather not confuse the user by automatically displaying choices > that they are less likely to want to select. Note that the current > implementation calls isSupported() before checking for the OS and Architecture > matches - this seems like it may be backwards. I agree.
> 3. The tool-chain integration is present and is supported on the current host, > but the tool-chain isn't installed (or can't be found). This requires tool- > chain specific logic which is why we have the current isSupported() callback. > The current MBS behavior, for project creation, is to not display the tool- > chain's project-types by default, but to display them if the user selects to > show all project-types. This seems like reasonable behavior *if* the user > wasn't expecting to use that tool-chain anyway. But if they did expect to be > able to use that tool-chain, they probably won't understand why the project- > types are not displayed by default. Maybe we should have a "Show Problems" > button, or a "Problems List" at the bottom, on the project-type selection > dialog that explains why tool-chains are being excluded from the list. I agree. The only thing I’m afraid of is that the more buttons we have, the more confusing the UI might seem for the user. Note: we have two lists in the project-type selection dialog: the project-type list and the configuration list, and the “support” status is actually tool-chain/configuration-based, not project-type-based. So the “Show problems” button will likely modify both the “project-type” and “configuration” lists that might be confusing. The other thing that could be done (either in addition to the “Show problems” button or instead of it) is to highlight the unsupported configurations and project-types, e.g. the unsupported configurations could be displayed in italic/red. This will also make the “problem list” status bar more effectively used together with the unsupported configs highlighting. I mean that the “problem list” status bar might not be very informative when it is reflecting the project-type support status, because the “support” status is tool-chain/configuration-based (not project-type-based). For the project-type it might only display e.g. “the following configurations are unsupported: <cfg1>, …<cfgN>”. Having the unsupported configurations highlighted, the user will be able to select any of those configurations and obtain the more-detailed “support” status info displayed in the “problem list” bar for that particular configuration. Actually we could use the highlighting mechanism to highlight the configurations/project-types not supported on the host platform (described in section# 2). These configurations/ptoject-types should be highlighted differently than those that are unsupported (described in this section). What do you think?
> The > isSupported mechanism needs to provide a way for the tool-chain code to return > its explanation of what is wrong, and, as Mikhail points out, we also need > default messages. The other, less likey, case here might be that the user has > done some sort of custom installation and set up environment variables, etc. to > make the tool-chain work, but the tool-chain isSupported code doesn't know > about it and so returns that the tool-chain is not installed. Do we need some > way to allow the user to override the decision? I think this could be reasonable.
> 4. The tool-chain integration is present, is supported on the current host, > and is installed, but the tool-chain knows that the build will fail for some > reason, including: > - Not licensed > - Wrong version of some component > - The user has edited the tool-chain and added a tool that won't work for one > of the reasons discussed above. Mikhail's suggestion of adding the isSupported > mechanism to Tool and Builder helps in this case. > Andrew's suggestion of marking the project with an error marker and disabling > building sounds good in this case. I agree.
> Should we break up the current isSupported() method into isInstalled() and > canBuild() methods that return a status such as Mikhail suggests? I suppose that each time the support status is queried, both the “install” and “build” status is needed, so probably the best solution is to have one “isSupported” method and to allow the status object returned by that method contain some support status flags instead of a simple Boolean value (supported/unsuported). The “status” object described in my previous comment in this case will contain: - the "support" status flags that might specify the following: i. the tool/tool-chain is installed/not installed ii. the tool/tool-chain can be used/can not be used for building - for the tool-chain: the list of IDs of the unsupported tools/builder. - the human-readable string representing the reason why the tool/tool-chain is
What do you think?
Thanks, Mikhail
(In reply to comment #8) > I agree. The only thing I’m afraid of is that the more buttons we have, the > more confusing the UI might seem for the user. > Note: we have two lists in the project-type selection dialog: the project-type > list and the configuration list, and the “support” status is actually > tool-chain/configuration-based, not project-type-based. > So the “Show problems” button will likely modify both the “project-type” and > “configuration” lists that might be confusing. > The other thing that could be done (either in addition to the “Show problems” > button or instead of it) is to highlight the unsupported configurations and > project-types, e.g. the unsupported configurations could be displayed in > italic/red. > This will also make the “problem list” status bar more effectively used > together with the unsupported configs highlighting. I mean that the “problem > list” status bar might not be very informative when it is reflecting the > project-type support status, because the “support” status is > tool-chain/configuration-based (not project-type-based). For the project-type > it might only display e.g. “the following configurations are unsupported: > <cfg1>, …<cfgN>”. Having the unsupported configurations highlighted, the user > will be able to select any of those configurations and obtain the more- > detailed “support” status info displayed in the “problem list” bar for that > particular configuration. > Actually we could use the highlighting mechanism to highlight the > configurations/project-types not supported on the host platform (described in > section# 2). These configurations/ptoject-types should be highlighted > differently than those that are unsupported (described in this section). > What do you think?
I like your suggestion for highlighting configurations/project-types that are unsupported as described in this section, but I'd rather leave the configurations/project-types that are unsupported on the host platform the way they are - that is, they only appear if the user selects the appropriate "Show All" button.
> I suppose that each time the support status is queried, both the “install” and > “build” status is needed, so probably the best solution is to have one > “isSupported” method and to allow the status object returned by that method > contain some support status flags instead of a simple Boolean value > (supported/unsuported). The “status” object described in my previous comment > in this case will contain: > - the "support" status flags that might specify the following: > i. the tool/tool-chain is installed/not installed > ii. the tool/tool-chain can be used/can not be used for building > - for the tool-chain: the list of IDs of the unsupported tools/builder. > - the human-readable string representing the reason why the > tool/tool-chain is > What do you think?
I agree.
Thanks, Leo Hello Everybody,
I would like to know the current status of the bug .Actually we are developing an C/C++ IDE and need the installed tool chain version to be checked.As discussed in previous posts I was able to check the version in isSupported() method.But when the project is build only a warning is given.I want to stop the building procedure here.Could anybody tell me a way around till the changes in CDT are made?
Regards -Sanchali I agree this is an issue. Not sure anyone is planning to work on this any time soon.
Bug.WithOutStack:
hi,
I've been showing CDT to a few people and have seen how many of them are bitten by not having a correct version of make on the path (when using the managed build system). In terms of out-of-the-box experience it would be great if these common failure cases could be detected.
I've seen both (a) failures due to non GNU make's (b) failures due to out-of-date versions of GNU Make for example, the version shipped from http://unxutils.sourceforge.net/ is 3.78.1. This version seems to erroneously report that the compiler/linker executables could not be found when they are on the path (using GNU Make 3.80 solve this)
one possiblity might be to detect when a build fails, execute "make -v" and parse the output looking for GNU and a version number. This would be brittle in both the output of the make command, and the customizability of the make command. The code could only report to the user if it could positively detect that the make command being used was not compatible with the make files being generated, otherwise it could remain silent? having had a quick first look at the source code, the place that I think this could be fixed would be org.eclipse.cdt.managedbuilder.internal.core.GeneratedMakefileBuilder.java
however, this is more general than the place where GNU Make becomes a dependency (GnuMakefileGenerator). Maybe to properly treat this, a IManagedBuilderMakefileGenerator2 interface would need creating with a callback for diagnosing build failure, or preemptively checking that the make tool is compatible with the generated make files (although care would be needed to avoid false negatives)
Hi Andrew,
I agree this should be fixed. I知 not sure that extending the buildfile generator is the best approach, since the tool-chain/tool/builder support info might be needed not only while makefile generation/building, but also while project creation, or when the project build properties are being displayed/edited, etc.
I've got the following proposal for fixing this:
Currently there is the isSupported mechanism that specifies the support/unsupport status on the tool-chain level. So currently an ISV can implement the isSupported call-back that would check for the builder version and specify that the tool-chain is not supported. This is not really informative for the user, since the user might need to know the exact reason why the tool-chain is not supported. More than that, in the future there will be the possibility to change tools in the tool-chain thus making the tool-chain level isSupported mechanism work incorrectly for the tool-chain with substituted tools. We could provide the capability to specify a per-tool/builder isSupported call-back, which will allow the isSupported mechanism function properly for the tool-chains with substituted tools and also will provide more valuable and informative information for the user. The IToolChain.isSupported method in this case will query all its tools and a builder for the support status (along with the tool-chain isSupported callback if present) and will return the appropriate support status.
What do others think?
Thanks, Mikhail Hi Mikhail,
That sounds interesting, but we'll have to think about when it is appropriate to display different types of error messages. For example, if the make version is out of date, do we allow the user to create a project with the tool-chain or not? Do we give an error message at project creation or when the user tries to build the project?
I think that we will also need to expand the isSupported interface to allow the callee to pass back a message describing why the tool/toolchain/etc is not supported - to display to the user in certain cases. We also need to consider which messages to display only once per CDT session, since isSupported is called for many reasons.
I think we need a detailed analysis of when isSupported is called now, and when it is appropriate to return certain types of error messages. We may need several different methods in the isSupported interface.
Leo I agree with Leo. (In reply to comment #3) Hi Leo,
> Hi Mikhail, > > That sounds interesting, but we'll have to think about when it is appropriate > to display different types of error messages. For example, if the make version > is out of date, do we allow the user to create a project with the tool-chain or > not? My opinion is that we should hide by default all project-types/configurations that will not build. If the builder is not supported, the project will not build in anyway, so I suppose we should hide project-types/configurations with builder unsupported.
>Do we give an error message at project creation or when the user tries to > build the project? I suppose that displaying some informative information could be useful both while project creation and while building, so I think the project-type/configuration selection page of the new project wizard could contain some status bar that would provide the user some more detailed information regarding project-type/configuration support status.
> > I think that we will also need to expand the isSupported interface to allow the > callee to pass back a message describing why the tool/toolchain/etc is not > supported - to display to the user in certain cases. I agree. We should also support the "default behavior", when no message is provided, e.g. MBS might generate the following message: "The following tools are not supported for this configuration: <tool-name1>, … ,<tool-name-N>"
> We also need to consider > which messages to display only once per CDT session, since isSupported is > called for many reasons. Currently the isSupported status is queried: 1. when creating a new project - to display only supported project-types/configurations by default. 2. when the project is being built - to display the warning message in case the project is unsupported 3. when the build property page is displayed – to display a warning message in the status bar in case the currently selected configuration is unsupported 4. when selecting the default configuration at the project creation – to select the supported configuration 5. In the "Create Configuration" dialog to display/hide unsupported configurations in the "Copy settings from" list.
I don’t think we need to change all the above queries to be only once per CDT session. Do you think we need to check and display the support status somewhere else once pre CDT session?
> > I think we need a detailed analysis of when isSupported is called now, and when > it is appropriate to return certain types of error messages. I agree.
>We may need > several different methods in the isSupported interface. Looking at the way the isSupported is used currently, I suppose we might need only to extend the isSupported to return some status object instead of Boolean value. The status might contain: - the "support" status that might specify the following: i. the tool/tool-chain is supported ii. the tool/tool-chain is not supported - for the tool-chain: the list of IDs of the unsupported tools/builder. - the human-readable string representing the reason why the tool/tool-chain is unsupported.
What do you think?
> > Leo
Regards, Mikhail
I would say hiding project types that won't build is not a good behaviour in the case where a user gets a fresh copy of eclipse, cdt and a toolchain that uses the managed build system - as when they go to start a new project, they might get a wizard that doesn't allow them to create one, because no builder is supported.
Some scenarios might be (1) tool/toolchain is not supported because of wrong platform (os/arch). I realize the line is fuzzy here around what constitutes and os/arch however.. (2) tool/toolchain is not supported because it is not installed (or present, or maybe licensed?) (3) tool/toolchain is present,licensed but the builder it relies upon cannot function
How about allowing project creation in all of the above, but subsequently marking the project with an error marker and disabling building?
The explanation would appear as the description of a high priority Problem. This is analogous to how Java Projects refuse to build until all of their project references are present.

I20051116-1332

Bug.Summery: Launcher messagebox "Do you really want to clear..." interprets "Escape" keypress as a "No" button click
Bug.WithStack: In a launch configuration "Main" tab check both "Clear workspace data before launching" and "Ask for confirmation before clearing". Run the configuration. In the "Do you want to clear the run-time workspace data in...." messagebox press the "Escape" key. The configuration starts as if the "No" button has been clicked, though the launch should have been canceled instead (same as the "Cancel" button has been clicked, as it is common with message boxes of that kind). Fixed. thanks for reporting.
Bug.WithOutStack: In a launch configuration "Main" tab check both "Clear workspace data before launching" and "Ask for confirmation before clearing". Run the configuration. In the "Do you want to clear the run-time workspace data in...." messagebox press the "Escape" key. The configuration starts as if the "No" button has been clicked, though the launch should have been canceled instead (same as the "Cancel" button has been clicked, as it is common with message boxes of that kind). Fixed. thanks for reporting.

Bug.Summery: Using many instances of builders with same ICommand.getBuilderName() can break
Bug.WithStack:
In some cases the internal build code uses the string returned from ICommand.getBuilderName() to find a specific builder to execute. However, it's possible to assign a project multiple instances of a given builder, and all report the same name. If explicitly invoking a request to build with that name, but intending the Map args for another builder than the first, things will break.
The whole concept is thus flawed. At this time, this primarily has been seen when at least two builders of the same type have been assigned and the second has been marked as an 'Assembly' builder. Putting builders in the reverse order works, i.e. all 'Assembly' builders must be first in the list (and only one instance of each given type).
After M2, redesign the current Buckminster builder mechanism entirely. A possible method is to virtualize all builders under a single concrete BuckminsterBuilder that in turn can manage a list of builders that it passes build requests to each similar to how AbstractBuckminsterBuilder does it today. Redesign into 'actions' are underway. This error is not really a bug in Buckminster - will place a bug for general Eclipse build management instead. -
Bug.WithOutStack:
In some cases the internal build code uses the string returned from ICommand.getBuilderName() to find a specific builder to execute. However, it's possible to assign a project multiple instances of a given builder, and all report the same name. If explicitly invoking a request to build with that name, but intending the Map args for another builder than the first, things will break.
The whole concept is thus flawed. At this time, this primarily has been seen when at least two builders of the same type have been assigned and the second has been marked as an 'Assembly' builder. Putting builders in the reverse order works, i.e. all 'Assembly' builders must be first in the list (and only one instance of each given type).
After M2, redesign the current Buckminster builder mechanism entirely. A possible method is to virtualize all builders under a single concrete BuckminsterBuilder that in turn can manage a list of builders that it passes build requests to each similar to how AbstractBuckminsterBuilder does it today. Redesign into 'actions' are underway. This error is not really a bug in Buckminster - will place a bug for general Eclipse build management instead. -

Bug.Summery: [Forms] Scrolling in forms leaves major cheese
Bug.WithStack:
I20051116-1332, GTK+ 2.6.10, KDE 3.4.1, X.org 6.8.2, Linux 2.6.13
I'll attach screenshots. It seems that scrolling in some parts of the editor for schema files is badly broken. I'll attach screenshots. Created attachment 30143 Initial State (Good) Created attachment 30144 Clicked on bottom line (Small Cheese) Created attachment 30145 Arrow Down (Big Cheese) Created attachment 30146 This is also happening in trees. (That was on a Mac BTW) How are forms implicated here? Forms are just SWT composites with controls and layouts. I would look at SWT first - we don't do anything interesting when it comes to widgets we host. Regarding comment #4 and comment #5, I cannot reproduce this problem on my machine, so it is likely an unrelated problem. Kim: can you file a separate bug? See bug 116892.

Bug.Summery: import plugins from search view
Bug.WithStack:
It would be nice to be able to import plugins into the workspace by selecting them from the search view. Here's the usecase:
I would like to find out which plugins contribute to a certain extension point. In order to do that I just go to the plugin.xml editor and click on the "Find References" link in the extension point page. The results are shown in the search view. Now I need to inspect the code from those plugins but they are not in my workspace so I cannot open the classes. It would be nice if from that search view I could just select (or multi-select) some plugins, right click and choose "Import". That would take me to the wizard for importing plugins having the selected plugins as input. +1 anything that makes it easier to manage plugins is good. Note that in this case I would have put "Add to target" rather than "import". Do you really want it in your workspace or do you just want it in your world? We already have a similar function available in the Plugins view, where you can select a plug-in and import it via a context menu item without having to go through the wizard.
Adding such a function to the search view would be good too. In this usecase I just want to open some Java classes from the plugin without modifying but I can easily see usecases where I need to modify them (for example when investigating a bug in a third party plugin). Janek, could you try to reuse strings from the plugins view context menu to save on translation? :-) Added plug-in import action group to the search view. did you remember to recycle? :-) Yes, 2 recycled strings - but I had to add 2 more.

Bug.Summery: [jar exporter] Clarify label for 'save description'

Lines.Line: 1. File -> Export -> JAR file
2. On the first page select all the resources that go into the JAR
3. On the second page check 'Save description...' and give a file name, e.g.
'myJarDescription.jardesc'
4. Press finish, JAR file and 'myJarDescription.jardesc' are created
5. To export the same files again:
- Select 'myJarDescription.jardesc', select 'Open JAR packager' from context
menu
- The same resource are selected as described in the JAR file
- If you change the selection, the JAR file description will be updated,
as the 'Save description...' checkbox is still selected.

1) I didn't know (till that response) what a *description* is in that context. I would have expected more or less the UI-convention about 'Save settings'. So, my suggestion is about renaming the label from
'Save the description of this JAR file in the workspace' to simply
'Save the description resp. settings of this JAR file'

2) The issue why I wouldn't have expected that functionallity behind it, is cause in the Import/Export => Export => Java there is no section with 'Description File' [or better 'JAR-setting file' resp. 'JAR-description file' (Tooltip: 'Generate a JAR-file from the existing Description File')
1) For 'clarify label'
2) Add an additional function in the Export-Dialog (Java) for JAR-Descritption files.
- Select 'myJarDescription.jardesc', select 'Open JAR packager' from context
menu
- The same resource are selected as described in the JAR file
- If you change the selection, the JAR file description will be updated,
as the 'Save description...' checkbox is still selected.

Bug.WithStack:
I export currently within short intervals my Project to a standalone-Java-app. I would wish to export my different settings all at once and do not wanna make my selection over and over again.
Especially the selection for the package is not very comfortable. I make several tests in a specific test-package, let them run, change my code, and don't care about the code there after successful testing. It could happen, that it gets defective.
So, the selection of the Packages are not kept, while the rest is.
So, either it's a FR or a bug. I guess more on a FR, but ... Which wizard exactly are you using here? Don't understand the Question.
I open the Navigator, select the Tree-Node, right click, Import/Export, Export/Java/JAR-File, Next, Selection of the Tree-Node is not kept in the JAR Package Specification :(
BTW: Version: 3.1.0 [!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! => should be 3.2.0 or not ?????????] Build id: I20050920-0010 You have to give more precise steps.
This is how it normally works: 1. File -> Export -> JAR file 2. On the first page select all the resources that go into the JAR 3. On the second page check 'Save description...' and give a file name, e.g. 'myJarDescription.jardesc' 4. Press finish, JAR file and 'myJarDescription.jardesc' are created 5. To export the same files again: - Select 'myJarDescription.jardesc', select 'Open JAR packager' from context menu - The same resource are selected as described in the JAR file - If you change the selection, the JAR file description will be updated, as the 'Save description...' checkbox is still selected.
Reopen if this doesn't work for you.
I reopen this Bug, although the description given works.
The main reason why I reopen this ticket, is cause I never ever would have expected to find that functionallity behind the 'Description...'. Reasons are as follows:
1) I didn't know (till that response) what a *description* is in that context. I would have expected more or less the UI-convention about 'Save settings'. So, my suggestion is about renaming the label from 'Save the description of this JAR file in the workspace' to simply 'Save the description resp. settings of this JAR file'
2) The issue why I wouldn't have expected that functionallity behind it, is cause in the Import/Export => Export => Java there is no section with 'Description File' [or better 'JAR-setting file' resp. 'JAR-description file' (Tooltip: 'Generate a JAR-file from the existing Description File')
Due to No 2) I do not understand the functionallity of 1) Especially since the word 'Description' is not used any longer (not even on the right-click) in the whole UI and does not fit into the/my common UI-language (which would be 'Settings').
My proposal is to provide functionallity 2) and then 1) would get more clearer. As a minor issue I see the renaming of the label as suggested in 1). I would be happy if, this Bug could be splitted into two:
1) For 'clarify label' 2) Add an additional function in the Export-Dialog (Java) for JAR-Descritption files.
What is your opinion? I don't think an entry in the export wizard makes sense. How would that wizard look like? Like the JAR exporter, but only creates a single description file? I'm not sure, if we are talking about the same issue. I talk about the Import/Export-Dialog.
First, I would introduce an entry in the Java-Section with the
Java-Description
which would give the user a more feeling, there is something.
When selecting, I would open a Browse-Dialog, similar to ... (have not found a suitable Dialog, but I guess, there is one already provided). And after this, continue the same way as you would right-click and open the JAR-Exporter-dialog.
My idea, what kind of functionallity are you talking about? That would be an import wizard: Import from description file, I guess.
Yeah, the second part of this Entry.
1) An import Description Wizard 2) Clarify the labels.
Since I see two issues, I guess it would be better to have two different Bugs. You open them? If I would, I probablly get lost again in the correct wordings. I'm not a fan of suggestion 1. So if you file a bug, I would set it to 'wont fix'. The reason is that this is not an import (nor an export). The jardesc.description is a script to repeat something you just did before. It would have been nice if it were an ANT file (see other bug requests for that). I find it very intuitive that you have context menu entries on it that run that script or open the wizard on it again. Feel free to decide if you want to file it anyways.
For the issue with the label we will se what we can improve. I filled a Bug 119004. I think the term "description" is good. If not clear or if one does not see how to recreate the same JAR, one can always use F1 to get more info.

Bug.Summery: Clicking "ok" on "Target Platform" pref page causes UI to hang
Bug.WithStack:
When I switch between from one target platform to another target platform, and then I click the ok button, the UI becomes unresponsive for about 1/2 minute. I'm using a pretty beefy computer (2Ghz/2GB RAM) too.
My hypothesis is some long running task is running on the UI thread. If this is the case, I suggest doing whatever is happening when "ok" is pressed on a background thread.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 97677 ***

When I switch between from one target platform to another target platform, and then I click the ok button, the UI becomes unresponsive for about 1/2 minute. I'm using a pretty beefy computer (2Ghz/2GB RAM) too.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 97677 ***

Bug.Summery: [Workbench] bundle-activator class implements IStartup results in double instantiation
Bug.WithStack:
If I declare an org.eclipse.ui.startup extension with class-attribute pointing to my plugin-activator class, this class seems to get instantiated twice. (Probably once from the startup-mechanism using createExecutableExtension, and once from the bundle activator.) This should be covered in the doc change as described in bug 91603. Passing to Nick for comment. Yes, it's documented in the extension point schema: "Do not specify the plug-in class as the value of the class attribute, or it will be instantiated twice (once by regular plug-in activation, and once by this mechanism)."
There's no easy way for the startup mechanism to know that the class specified for the startup extension is a plugin class before instantiating it. If there was, we could at least check if the given class name is the same as the plugin class for the plugin containing the extension.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 91603 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
If I declare an org.eclipse.ui.startup extension with class-attribute pointing to my plugin-activator class, this class seems to get instantiated twice. (Probably once from the startup-mechanism using createExecutableExtension, and once from the bundle activator.) This should be covered in the doc change as described in bug 91603. Passing to Nick for comment. Yes, it's documented in the extension point schema: "Do not specify the plug-in class as the value of the class attribute, or it will be instantiated twice (once by regular plug-in activation, and once by this mechanism)."
There's no easy way for the startup mechanism to know that the class specified for the startup extension is a plugin class before instantiating it. If there was, we could at least check if the given class name is the same as the plugin class for the plugin containing the extension.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 91603 ***

Bug.Summery: Scroll clipped Tree/Table causes pixel corruption (drawing problem)

Lines.Line: 1. open the plugin.xml editor
2. Make sure there is something under the editor, like the console view
3. Go to the build tab
4. Arrange the views and editor so that there are scroll bars present on both
the editor and the binary build list
5. Scroll the editor so that the binary build list is partially obscured by the view under the editor
6. Scroll the binary build list
1. open a plugin editor with a view under it
2. select any editor tab that has a list with enough items in it for a scroll bar to be present (e.. Dependencies with a lot of required plugins)
3. increase the size of the view under the editor until the list is obscured partially
4. move the list's scrollbar and observe cheese
The "PI code that reproduces the problem" attachment points to a bug in carbon (that we may or may not be able to work around).
*** Bug 253132 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Created attachment 191420
fix

Bug.Summery: [launching] Workspace not refreshed after external tools run
Bug.WithStack:
I'm running Maven 2 using an External Tools Runner and I have configured the Refresh tab to refresh the whole workspace upon completion. When I run a Maven task that affects a jar in my repository in a way that should cause one of my other projects in the workspace to no longer compile, the change it not reflected until I manually refresh the project.
I have seen the refresh behavior work properly with the Ant Build runner. This looks like nothing is happening Move to Platform/Ant I cannot reproduce this problem on Eclipse 3.2 M4.
Do you see the refresh occur but the change is not picked up or does not refresh occur at all? Should be quite easy to tell by checking in the Progress view after completion of the external tool. It seems to do something really fast after the Maven build completes. I can see a little progress indicator flash on the bottom right, but too quickly to read it.
In trying this again, the first thing I did was re-run the External Tool launcher that I set up when I filed this bug. When I did that, I did see a full refresh of the whole workspace. It took several seconds and I could watch the progress in the bottom right. However, the project that I was interested in refreshing (call it project B) was not open at the time. Once I opened B, made a change to the project on which it depends (project A), I re-ran the External Tool launcher again and this time saw only the quickest of flashes and no aparent refresh. Selecting project B and hitting F5 forced a refresh and the compile errors I expected showed up.
Project B uses a build path that is configured by the Maven 2 eclipse plugin (eclipse:eclipse). The dependency is in the form of a jar in the Maven repository and shows up as a Library in the build path.
Let me know if you need more info. On the refresh tab, "Recursively include sub-folders" is toggled? Yes, I have "Refresh Resources upon completion" ticked, "The Entire Workspace" ticked, and "Recursively include sub-folders" ticked.

Bug.Summery: Instrument autobuild interruption
Bug.WithStack:
Build: I20051115
I have noticed autobuild frequently being interrupted if it runs soon after startup. There should be an instrumentation flag to help in debugging this - i.e., what thread is trying to modify the workspace at this time that is causing the build to be interrupted? Added instrumentation. The new .options file value is:
# Reports the cause of autobuild interruption org.eclipse.core.resources/build/interrupt=false
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build: I20051115
I have noticed autobuild frequently being interrupted if it runs soon after startup. There should be an instrumentation flag to help in debugging this - i.e., what thread is trying to modify the workspace at this time that is causing the build to be interrupted? Added instrumentation. The new .options file value is:
# Reports the cause of autobuild interruption org.eclipse.core.resources/build/interrupt=false

Bug.Summery: System.out showing up in Ant output

Lines.Line: 1. Delete it.
2. Use IProgressMonitor (for progress information intended for the user).
3. Use IStatusHandler (for bulk information intended for the user).
4. Use ILog (for internal logging/tracing/debugging purposes).

Bug.WithStack:
I am seeing quite a few printlns in the console when I run the Ant tasks. These need to be cleaned up. If they are necessary output they should go through the logging mechanism and be moved into translatable strings.
Reproduce by running wsgen Ant task for client and service scenarios. Though functionally not major, the extraneous println()s will impair the quality of the Ant tasks insofar as the intended output of the Ant tasks will be obfuscated by this additional (untranslated) text. One of four courses of action should be taken for each println: 1. Delete it. 2. Use IProgressMonitor (for progress information intended for the user). 3. Use IStatusHandler (for bulk information intended for the user). 4. Use ILog (for internal logging/tracing/debugging purposes).
If in doubt on any given case, contact the custodian of the class. The println's that are showing up are primarily in the "Pre" commands. Output from the Ant task as follows:
... [wsgen] In Pre service develop command. [wsgen] AreaServiceSOAPImpl.java already exists, WSDL2Java will not overwrite it. [wsgen] In Pre service assemble command. [wsgen] In Pre service deploy command. [wsgen] In Pre service install command. [wsgen] In Pre service run command. Created attachment 30177 *package* level patch for - org.eclipse.jst.ws.internal.consumption.ui.wsrt

Bug.Summery: [CommonNavigator] CommonViewer should have option to not use decorating label provider
Bug.WithStack:
Currently, the CommonViewer uses a decorating label provider by default and has no explicit way to change that. I'm sure I could do it if I tried but there should be an explicit way to do it. One option would be to have a getLabelProvider method that subclasses could override in order to wrap (i.e. it assumes that the default behavior would not use a decorating label provider). Another would be to have an explicit style bit that indicated whether decoration was desired or not. I also noticed that their is some behavior in CommonNavigator that could potentially line in the CommonViewer. For example, the sorting, filtering and actions support is in the navigator but not in the viewer.
On a related note, one thing we did in the sync view is create a separate class (which we called an advisor for a lack of a better term) that configured a viewer for use by the synchronization framework. The advantage of this was that the advisor could be used with any AbstractTreeViewer. For instance, if you want to support the use of the Common content providers in a checkbox tree viewer using subclassing, you will need to duplicate all the code in CommonViewer. This approach may not do away with the ned to subclass but it will reduce the amount of code that needs to be duplicated.
I am currently working on a demo in which I will need to add action support to the CommonViewer. If you would like, I can prototype the above while I'm doing it and see how it goes. Just noticed that there is a StructuredViewerManager and a CommonNavigatorManager which are similar to what I descibed.
The CommonNavigatorManager extracts most of the logic for the types of things that an Advisor might do. If you want to prototype a modification, I think that would be fine. I would start with the CommonNavigatorManager class as a starting point for that work (or provide feedback on how the Advisor is different).
I really should read all of the comments before responding to the email notifications ....
StructuredViewerManager is less an advisor role and more to allow extensions to be intialized (inputChanged()) after the fact.
Recall that when the viewer is started, some or most of its extensions are not loaded. When a content provider is created, it must be initialized with the current viewer (inputChanged()) to provide the illusion that it's been active all along. The StructuredViewerManager handles the logic to initialize new content providers and to update all existing when the input changes.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 119208 ***

Another would be to have an explicit style bit that indicated whether decoration was desired or not. StructuredViewerManager is less an advisor role and more to allow extensions to be intialized (inputChanged()) after the fact.
Recall that when the viewer is started, some or most of its extensions are not loaded. When a content provider is created, it must be initialized with the current viewer (inputChanged()) to provide the illusion that it's been active all along. The StructuredViewerManager handles the logic to initialize new content providers and to update all existing when the input changes.

Bug.Summery: Using -verbose in aop.xml does not yield info messages
Bug.WithStack:
The interpretation of the -verbose option for LTW is not consistent with other uses in AspectJ e.g. ajc, iajc. It should allow info as well as warining and error messages to be output. The option parser and testcase need to be updated. Created attachment 30193 Fix and modified testcases
Change LTW options parsing and change LTWLog testcase to use harness matthew - does this patch clash with another one? since I've applied it just now and some LTW related tests are failing for me. committed - will be in next build. fixes available

Bug.Summery: [DetachedViews] Floating (undocked) views miss some keyboard events
Bug.WithStack:
When you undock (using drag&drop) a view with, for example, package explorer to its own window and try to use DELETE key to delete a file, the deletion will occur in the editor in the main window.
I have a dual monitor and use floating windows quite frequently to leave more space for the source editor. I created a UML2 diagram and then decided to delete it. I selected it in the package explorer and pressed DELETE key from keyboard. Instead of deleting the file, Eclipse deleted a character in my Java source editor at the current cursor position. Note that the cursor is not visible at this moment because the focus is on the undocked package explorer. I will attach a screen-shot of the undocked window.
I posted it on the eWorkbench because it looks like a window management problem of the RCP's workbench.
Thanks Created attachment 30159 Screenshot of the undocked window Sorry, you have the wrong Product and Component. eRCP is for devices, not desktop. You probably want Product "platform". (In reply to comment #2)
Sorry about that.
Now, how can I move this report to "Platform"? When I tried to move it I got an error saying that only the submitter or a privileged user can move the bug. It's strange since I am the submitter.
(In reply to comment #3)
Nevermind. I moved it.
Another small observation is the way the undocked windows behave relative to modal dialogs. In Windows XP if you try to activate a window blocked by a modal dialog you will hear a blocking sound and the modal dialog will blink for a couple of seconds to indicate that it blocks the window you are trying to activate. However when you try to activate an undocked window only the blocking sound is made but no blinking is seen.
This appears to work now...
